set.p: The action takes place at a small pavilion situated in the park belonging to an old castle .

stage.head: STREAKS OF LIGHT
stage.stage: An octagonal pavilion of the Rococo period , the three front walls of which are cut off by the proscenium . Ceiling and walls are cracked and spotted by rain , and bear the marks of long disuse . At the back , in the centre , a large doorway . The glass door is thrown wide open ; the shutters behind are closed . On the right and left , in the oblique walls of the room , are windows , the shutters of which are also closed . Through the blinds at the door and the right window , sunbeams in streaks of light penetrate the semi-darkness of the room .

On the left , in the foreground , a Louis Sixteenth sofa with table and gilded chairs to match . On the wall above , an old mirror . Near the sofa , a tapestried doorway . A chandelier wrapped in a dusty gauze covering is suspended from the ceiling . A four-post bed with hangings of light net takes up the right side of the stage . In the foreground , in front of the bed , a table with plates , glasses , wine-decanters , and provisions on it . A coffee percolator stands under the table . In the middle of the stage , a little to the right , a chaise-longue . At the head of it , a small table . Between the large door and the windows , dusty marble busts on dilapidated pedestals . Above them , on the walls , a collection of various sorts of weapons . The Oriental rugs which are thrown about the floor and over the chaise-longue contrast strangely with the faded splendour of the past .

The whole room is decorated with roses . On the table at the left is a bronze vessel of antique design overflowing with roses . Garlands of roses hang from the chandelier and encircle the bedposts . On the small table near the chaise-longue , a large , flat dish , also filled with roses . In fact wherever there is any place for these flowers , they have been used in profusion .
Part of the table which stands in front of the sofa is covered by a napkin , upon which are seen a bottle of wine and the remains of a luncheon for one . It is a sultry afternoon in midsummer .

Julia lies on the chaise-longue , asleep . She is a beautiful woman , about twenty-five years of age , intractable and passionate , with traces of a bourgeois desire to be “ romantic . ” She is dressed in white , flowing draperies , fantastically arranged .
A tower clock strikes four . Then the bells of the castle are heard ringing . Both seem to be at a distance of about two hundred paces .

Pierre enters cautiously through the tapestried doorway at the left . He is a fashionably dressed , aristocratic young fellow who has been petted and spoiled . He is effeminate , cowardly , arrogant , and is trying to play the passionate man , although inwardly cold and nervous .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Laughs in her sleep . Her laughter dies out in groans .Pierre ! Pierre ! Help ! Pierre ! Pierrebending over herYes , yes . What is it ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Nothing —Laughs and goes on sleepingPierrestraightening upWhew How hot it is !He stares at Julia , his face distorted by fear and anger , and beats his forehead . Then indicating the outstretched form of the woman .Beautiful !— You beautiful animal — you !Kneels . Julia holds out her arms to him , but he evades her embrace .Stop ! Wake up ! JuliatearfullyPlease let me sleep .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: No ! Wake up ! I 've only come for a moment . It 's tea-time , and I have to go back to the house .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Please stay !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: No , mamma will be asking for me . I have to be there for tea . JuliapettishlyI have a headache . I want some black coffee !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Then make it yourself . The gardener is cleaning the orchid rooms in the hot-house , and he has no time for you now .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: He never has time for me !— And the meals that his wife cooks are simply abominable !— And the wine is always warm !— Do , for mercy 's sake , steal the key to the icehouse !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: But you know that I can n't !— I always bring you all the ice that I can manage to take from the table . If I insist upon having the key , the housekeeper will tell mamma .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But I wo n't drink warm wine — so there ! That 's what gives me these headaches .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Your headaches , I want to tell you , come from the roses . Ugh !— this nasty smell from the withered ones — sour — like stale tobacco smoke — why , it burns the brains out of one 's head !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: See here , dearie , you let the roses alone ! That was our agreement , you know — basketsful , every morning ! I wish the gardener would bring even more ! That 's what he 's bribed for .— More ! More ! Always more !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: See here , if you were only reasonable ——

lg.l: But I 'm not reasonable ! O you — you —
lg.stage: She holds out her arms to him . He comes to her . They kiss .
lg.l: More !— More !— No end !— Ah , to die !——

sp.speaker: Oh !
sp.p: Julia .

sp.speaker: To die !
sp.p: Pierrewith hidden scornYes — to die .Yawning nervously .Pardon me !— It 's as hot as an oven in here .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And the shutters are always closed ! For eight long days I 've seen nothing of the sun except these streaks of light . Do open the shutters — just once !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: For Heaven 's sake !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Just for a second !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: But do n't you realize that the pavilion is locked and that not a soul ever crosses the threshold ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Oh , yes , I know — because your lovely , reckless great-grandmother lost her life here a hundred years ago ! That 's one of those old-wives ’ tales that everyone knows .— Who can tell ? Perhaps my fate will be the same as hers .— But do open the shutters !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Do be reasonable ! You know that in order to come in here by the side door without being seen I have to crawl through the woods for a hundred yards . The same performance twice a day — for a week ! Now , if I should open the shutters and one of the gardener 's men should see it , why , he 'd come , and then ——

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Let him come ! I 'll smile at him — and he 's no man if he does n't keep quiet after that ! Why , your old gardener would cut his hand off for me any day of his life — just for a bit of wheedling !— It can n't be helped — they all love me ! Pierreaside

sp.speaker: Beast !
sp.p: Julia . What were you muttering then ?Pierre throws himself down before her and weeps .Pierre ! Crying ?— Oh !— Please do n't — or I 'll cry too . And my head aches so ! Pierresoftly but nervously and with hatredDo you know what I 'd like to do ? Strangle you !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Ha ! Ha ! Ha !—pityinglyDear me ! Those soft fingers — so weak !— My little boy has read in a naughty book that people strangle their loves — and so he wants to do some strangling too ! PierrerisingWell , what 's to become of you ? How much longer is the game to last in this pavilion ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: As long as the roses bloom — that was agreed , you know .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Bah ! Then !— Why think of it ? I 'm here now , here under the protection of your lovely , ghostly great-grandmother . No one suspects — no one dreams ! My husband is searching for me the whole world over !— That was a clever notion of mine — writing him from Brussels — Nora , last act , last scene — and then coming straight back again ! I 'll wager he 's in Paris now , sitting at the Cafe des Anglais , and looking up and down the street — now toward the Place de l'Opera , now toward the Madeleine . Will you wager ? I 'll go you anything you say . Well , go on , wager !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: On anything else you wish — but not on that !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Because your husband was at the castle this morning . Juliarising hastilyMy husband — was — at the castle ——?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: What 's so surprising about that ? He always used to come , you know — our nearest neighbour — and all that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Did he have a reason for coming ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: A special reason ?— No .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Pierre — you 're concealing something from me ! PierrehesitatingNothing that I know of . No .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Why did n't you come at once ? And now — why have you waited to tell me ? PierresullenlyYou 're hearing it soon enough .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Pierre , what happened ? Tell me , exactly !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Well , he came in the little runabout — without a groom — and asked for mamma . I naturally pretended to be going out . But you know how she always insists on my staying with her .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And how was he was he — just the same as ever ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh , no , I would n't say that .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: How did he look ? Tell me , tell me !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: In the first place , he wore black gloves — like a gravedigger .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Ha ! Ha ! And what else ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: In the second place , he was everlastingly twitching his legs .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And what else ? What else ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh , he explained that you were at a Hungarian watering-place , that you were improving , and that you were expected home soon .Julia bursts out laughing .Yes ,gloomilyit 's screamingly funny , is n't it .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: So I 'm at a Hungarian watering-place ! Ha ! Ha ! Ha !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: But he looked at me so questioningly , so — so mournfully — why , it was really most annoying the way he looked at me .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: At a Hungarian watering-place !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: And then , later , mamma said to him , “ It 's a dreadful pity your dear wife is n't here just now . She does so love the roses . ”

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And what did he say ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: “ Our roses are not thriving very well this year , ” said he .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But his turnips !— They always thrive !— And then ——?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Then a strange thing occurred that I can n't help worrying about . Suddenly mamma said to him , “ Something very peculiar is happening on our estate this year . Now I can see from where I sit that the whole place is one mass of roses . And yet , if at any time I ask for a few more than usual , there are none to be had ! ”

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Why , you must have been shaking in your boots ! Did you do anything to betray us ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh , I think I know how to take care of myself !— But suddenly he grew absolutely rigid — as if — as if he had been reflecting . He acted like a man who sleeps with his eyes open . Mamma asked him a question three times , and he never answered a word !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: I say , did you come here to frighten me ? Pierrebursting outWhat is your fear compared to what I had to stand ! Compared to my biting , nauseous shame as I sat there opposite him ?— I scorned the man inwardly , and yet I felt as if I ought to lick the dust on his boots . When mamma said to him , “ You do n't look very well , Herr Wittich — are you ill ? ” — her words were like the box on the ear that she gave me when , as a lad of fifteen , I got into mischief with the steward 's daughter .— Why did you drag me into this loathsome business ? I do n't like it !— I wo n't stand it !— I like to feel straight ! I want my hands clean !— I want to look down on the people that I meet !— I owe that to myself .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Reproaches ?— I 'd like to know who has the guilty conscience in this case , you or I ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: How long have you been concerned about your conscience ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Pierre , you know I had never belonged to any other man — except him .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: But you 've showered sweet glances right and left . You 've flirted with every man who would look at you — even the stable-boy was n't beneath your notice !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And he was better than you !— For he wanted nothing more than to follow me with his eyes . But you , Pierre , you were not so easily satisfied . No , the young Count was more exacting . Corrupt to the core — in spite of his twenty years —— PierreproudlyI am not a bit corrupt . I am a dreamer . My twenty years excuse that !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But your dreams are poisonous . You want a woman to be your mistress and yet be chaste — to keep the blush of maidenhood and yet be as passionate as yourself .— And what have you learned from your experience in the world ? Nothing , except how to scent and track out the sins that lie hidden in one 's inmost soul , the secret sins that one dares not admit to oneself .— And when the prey is in reach , then you fire away with your “ rights of the modern woman , ” your “ sovereignty of the freed individuality ” — and whatever the rest of the phrases may be .— Ah ! You knew better than I that we all have the Scarlet Woman 's blood in our veins !— Blow away the halo — and the saint is gone !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: It seems to me you found a great deal of pleasure in your sin !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Yes — at least that 's what one tells oneself — perhaps one feels it , too .— It depends — more in the evening than the morning — more in March than October .— But the dread , the horror of it , is always there .— The weight of such love is like the weight of one 's own coffin-lid .— And you soon discovered that , Pierre .— Then you began softly , gently , to bind me to you with glances and caresses that were like chains of roses !— Yes , and that I become maddened by roses as cats by valerian , that , too , you soon found out .— Then — then you began to speak to me of the lover 's pavilion — all covered with roses — where your ancestors spent happy , pastoral hours in wooing their loves — the pavilion that had been waiting so long for a new mistress . You spoke of adorning it with beautiful hangings — of filling it full of roses . Oh you , you Pierre , how well you understood !— Do have some black coffee made for me ! If the gardener can n't do it , make it yourself ! Please , please !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: But , I tell you , I have to go back to mamma .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Nowadays , you always “ have to go back to mamma . ” Shall I tell you something — a big secret ? You are tired of me ! You want to get rid of me — only you do n't know how !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Your notions are offensive , my dear .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Pierre , I know my fate . I know I am doomed to the gutter . But not yet ! Do n't leave me yet ! Care for me a little while longer — so the fall wo n't be too sudden .— Let me stay here as long as the roses bloom — here , where he can n't find me ! Oh , if I leave this place I shall die of fear !— Nowhere else am I safe from those two great fists of his !— Pierre , Pierre , you do n't know his fists — they 're like two iron bolts !— You , too — beware of him ! Pierrehalf to himselfWhy do you say that to me ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: He was always jealous of you . When you sent the hothouse roses in April , he became suspicious . Ever since then , he has continually had the notion of an admirer in his head . That was the danger-signal ! Pierre , if he surmised — then you would be the first — and I would come afterward ! Pierre , if you drive me to desperation , I 'll give you up to him !——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Are you mad ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: I 'll write him a letter something like this : “ If you want to find the traces of my flight , search the rubbish heap behind the lover 's pavilion . Search for the faded petals of the roses upon which , night after night , Pierre and I celebrated our union . Search the highway for the bloody prints of my bare feet after he turned me out . Then search the dregs of the brothels where I found a refuge . And then — then avenge me ! ”

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: You 'll do nothing of the kind , you —Seizes her by the wrists .JulialaughingNonsense ! You have no strength !Disengages herself without difficulty .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: You 've taken it out of me , you beast !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Beast ?— You 've been muttering that word now for a couple of days . This is the first time that you have flung it in my face .— What have I done that was bestial except to throw my young life at your feet ?— And so this is the end of our rose-fete ?—— Pierrein a low voice , breathing with difficultyNo , not yet — the end is still to come !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: I dare say .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: In fact — you must — leave here .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: I dare say .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Do you understand ?— You must leave this place — at once !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: H 'm — just so .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: For — you must know — you are no longer safe here . Juliaturning paleNot here either ?— Not even here ?——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: I did n't tell you everything , before .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Are you up to some new trick now ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: After I had accompanied him down the steps , he asked — very suddenly — to see the park .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: The park ——?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Yes . And he seemed to be searching every rose-bush as if to count the number of blossoms that had been cut from it . Then — in the linden lane — I kept pushing to the left — he kept pushing to the right , straight for the pavilion . And as it stood before us —— Juliaterrified

sp.speaker: The pavilion ?
sp.p: Pierre .

sp.speaker: Certainly
sp.p: Juliashuddering

sp.speaker: So near !
sp.p: Pierre . He said he 'd like to see the old thing once , from the inside .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Good heavens ! But he knows that 's impossible — he knows your family history !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: And you may be sure that 's how I put it to him .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And what did he ——?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: He was silent — and went back .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Went back ! But he 'll return !——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: You 've dumped me into a pretty mess , you have !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Do , for goodness ’ sake , stop pitying yourself , and tell me what 's to be done .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Have n't I told you ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: I 'll not go away ! I will not go away ! He can n't come in here ! I will not leave this place !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Listen ! I 'll have a carriage here — at one o'clock in the night — behind the park wall . Take it as far as the station .— Listen , I tell you !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: No , no , no ! As soon as I step into the street , I 'm lost . And you , too ! You do n't know him ! Gentle and tractable as he seems , when once he 's angry , his blood boils over !— If I had n't taken the cartridges out of his revolver in those days , he — Why , I 've seen him pick up two unmanageable boys on our place and swing them over his shoulder into the mill stream ! And they would have been ground to pieces , too , if he had n't braced himself against the shaft . Pierre , Pierre , never get into his way again . He 's merciless ! Pierrefeigning indifferenceOh , nonsense ! I can hit the ace of hearts at twenty paces ! I 'll show him !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Yes , you 'll “ show him ” ! Do you suppose that he 's going to wait until you take a shot at him ?— Devilish much he cares about your duels ! He 'd make a clod of earth out of you before you 'd have time to take off your hat !— I tell you , bolt the gate , lock every room in the house , hide behind your mother 's chair ,— and even there you wo n't be safe from him !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Struggling against his growing apprehension .If that 's the case , then — h 'm , then the best thing for me to do is to disappear for a time . Juliatrying to cling to himYes , let 's go away together ! Pierremoving asideThat might suit you .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But , after all , it would do no good . We could hide among crowds of people — in Piccadilly or in Batignolles — we could go to India or to Texas — and yet , if he took it into his head , he would find us none the less . Even if we should evade him — some day , sooner or later , you would have to return — and then — you would have to pay the penalty ! PierrestammeringI — would — have to —— JuliawildlySo stay — stay here ! Go and shoot him down !— at night — from behind !— It does n't matter ! Only — let — me — breathe — again .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Do you want to drive me mad ? Do n't you see that I 'm trembling all over ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Because you 're a cad and a coward — because ——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Yes , yes — anything , for all I care ! But go ! Leave my property ! Insult me , spit on me ,— but go !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And what then ? What then ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Ca n't you write to him ? Tell him that you have come back from your little journey — that you have reconsidered — that you can n't live without him . Tell him to forget — and all shall be as it was before .— Now , would n't that be splendid ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Now when he suspects ?— When he can follow me , step by step , here to this pavilion and back again ?Contemptuously .Splendid !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Then try something else !— Oh , now I have it ! Now I have it !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Speak , Pierre , for God 's sake , speak ! I 'll love you as —! Speak ! Speak !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: You know him . His heart is soft ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Yes , except when he 's in a rage , then ——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: And you are sure that he loves you deeply ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: If he did n't love me so much , what need we fear ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Good ! Well then , take a carriage at the station and drive home ; throw yourself at his feet and tell him everything . Tell him , for all I care , that you hate me — that you loathe me — I do n't mind — grovel before him until he raises you . And then all will be well !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Ah , if it were possible !— It would be deliverance — it would be heaven ! I should be safe once more — a human being !— I should see the sun again , instead of these streaks of light !— I should breathe the fresh air , instead of this musty odour of dead roses !— I should n't have to sink down , down into the filth !— I should n't have to be a bad woman — even if I am one !— There would be a respectable divorce — or perhaps merely a separation . For , I no longer dare hope to live with him as his wife , even if I were satisfied to be no better than his dog for the rest of my days !— Ah , but it cannot be ! It cannot be ! You do n't know him . You do n't know what he 's like when the veins stand out on his forehead !— He would kill me !— Rather than that — kill me yourself !— Here — now — this moment !— Get your duelling pistols . Oh no ! There — there — there are plenty of weapons !She pulls at the weapons on the wall , several of which fall clattering upon the floor .Swords — daggers — here !Throws an armful on the chaise-longue .They are rusty — but that does n't matter .— Take one ! Stab me first — then — do as you please !— Live if you can — do !— live as happily as you can ! Your life is in your hands .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Yes — I dare say . Live !— But how ? Where ?Sobs chokingly .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Come , then — we 'll die together — together !They sink into each other 's arms and remain motionless in mute despair . After a time , Julia raises her head cautiously and looks about her .Pierre ! Pierretroubled

sp.speaker: Well ?
sp.p: Julia . Has it occurred to you ? Perhaps it is n't so , after all !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Perhaps we 've just been talking ourselves into this notion , little by little — think so ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: You mean that he really wanted to do nothing but — look at the pavilion ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Well , it 's possible , you know .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Yes — at least nothing very unusual occurred .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But your naughty , naughty conscience came and asserted itself . Ha ! Ha ! What a silly little boy it is ! A downright stupid little boy !

lg.l: My imagination was always rather easily aroused . I ——
Such a stupid boy !— Pierre , let 's make some coffee — for a change , eh ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: But you know — I have to ——

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Dear me , mamma has had her tea long ago . Tell her you sat down in the shade — and fell asleep — anything ! It 's growing a bit shady here now . See there ! The streaks of light have gone .Indicates a corner of the room in which the streaks of light have just grown dim .Ah ! but how hot it is !Tears her dress open at the throat , breathing heavily .Will you bring me the coffee-pot , like a good boy ? PierrelistlesslyOh , well — all right .Carries the coffee-pot to the table .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Pierre , you — you could n't open the small door just a tiny bit ? No one would look into the shrubbery .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Well , out there in the shrubbery , it 's even hotter than in here .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Oh , just try it — wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Well , you 'll see !Opens the door at the left .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Whew ! It 's like a blast from a furnace ! And that disgusting odour — a mixture of perspiration and bad perfume — ugh !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: That 's from the roses of our by-gone days — they lie out there in great heaps .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Close the door ! Hurry — close it ! Pierredoes soI told you how it would be !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Well , perhaps you could adjust the shutters at the large door so that we 'd get more fresh air in here .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Even that would be dangerous . If some one happened to be looking this way and saw the movement —— Juliagoing to the doorOne has to do it slowly , ve-ry slow-ly —She starts , uttering a low cry of fear , and retreats to the foreground , her arms outstretched as if she were warding off a ghost .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Sh ! Sh !Approaches him cautiously , then softly .There 's a man — out there .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Hush ! Come here you can see it against the light .They cautiously change places . Pierre utters a low shriek , then Julia , softly , despairinglyPierre !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: It must be the gardener .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: It 's not — the — gardener .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Who is it then ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Creep around — and lock — the glass door . Pierreweak from fright

sp.speaker: I can n't
sp.p: Julia . Then I will .She has taken but a few steps toward the door when the streaks of light again become visible .He 's gone now !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: How — gone ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: There — there — nothing ——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Seize the opportunity — and go .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: To the gardener 's house — quick — before he comes back .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: In broad daylight — half dressed as I am ?

lg.l: Throw on a wrap — anything — hurry !

He is a large , burly man of about forty , whose whole appearance betrays neglect ; his sandy-coloured hair is pushed back from his forehead in damp strands ; his beard is straggling and unkempt ; his face is haggard and perspiring , his eyes lustreless . He staggers heavily in walking . He speaks in a stammering , hesitating voice ; he gives the impression , in sum , of a man who is deathly ill , but is making an intense effort to hold himself together .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: I beg your pardon if I am disturbing you .Both stare at him without venturing to move .Pierretaking heartOh — p-p-please ——

lg.l: I see you were about to make coffee . Really — I do n't want to ——

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Well , then we may as well — settle — our affair — first .Julia , who has been standing quite still , panting , utters a low groan . At the sound of her voice , Wittich catches his breath as if suffocating , then sinks into one of the chairs at the left and stares vacantly at the floor .Pierreedging up to Julia then softlyCan you understand this ? Juliaglancing back — aside to PierreKeep near the weapons ! Pierreas Wittich moves

sp.speaker: Hush !
sp.p: Wittich . You must forgive me — I only wanted to — look after — my — wife .Breaks down again .Pierreaside to JuliaWhy , he 's quite out of his mind !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Keep near the weapons !

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: I do n't care — to settle — this matter — by means of a — so-called — affair of honour . I 'm a plain man . I only know about such things from hearsay . And any way — I do n't see that they help — m-matters much .Breaks into tearless sobs .PierreasideHe wo n't hurt us . JuliastammeringI simply — do n't — understand it — at all ! Pierrepointing to WittichTry it ! Go to him !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: He 's not a bit like himself .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Go on ! Go on !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Who has timidly approached her husband , bid has drawn back at a movement of his , suddenly throws herself at his feet with great emotion .George ! George !— I am guilty !— I have sinned before God and you !— I acknowledge my crime !— My life is in your hands !— Crush me — grind me to dust !— But God knows , I only obeyed a wretched impulse . My love for you has never left my heart .— My one desire is to die . Kill me !— Here !— Now !— But forgive me ! Ah , forgive me ! Wittichstaring straight aheadYes , they always talk like that — in books , at least .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Forgive me !

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: There is nothing to forgive . And I am not going to kill any one . What good would it do ?Julia sobs , hiding her face in her hands .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Well , then — do n't kneel there — like that — Julia , dear !

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: I shall lie here until he raises me . Raise me ! Take me in your arms ! Oh , George ——

lg.l: Yes , that 's what they always say .
Well — h 'm — I suppose I may assume ,
Herr Wittich , that you had some purpose in seeking this interview ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Yes — yes .Looking about him .I can well imagine that my wife — er — that the lady must find it very pleasant here .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh , yes — we need n't hesitate to say that , need we , Julia , dear ? Juliauncertainly adopting his toneNo , indeed , Pierre , dear .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: At least — she seems to have plenty of roses here . Julialaughing nervouslyOh , yes — plenty .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: May I ask whether the lady has made any arrangements for the future ? Juliastill timidlyI was thinking of making my home in Paris , was n't I , Pierre ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Yes . You see , Julia wants to live a life suited to her tastes and inclinations — a life such as she cannot have even here — a life consecrated to Beauty and Art .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: They say that an existence of that sort comes high . Has my wife — er — has the lady made any provision for her expenses ? PierreembarrassedFrom the moment that I become of age I shall be in a position to — h 'm — h 'm ——

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: I see . But until that moment —?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: I — er ——

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Well , I consider it my duty — and mine alone — to protect the woman whom — until recently — I called my wife . And to save her from ruin , I am willing to make any sacrifice whatsoever .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh , as for that , of course ——

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: I intend to put no obstacle in the way of your desire to legitimize your relations .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Very kind of you — really — very thoughtful indeed .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Not because — not that I do n't dare insist upon my rights in this affair , but because I want to guard her from lifelong misery .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Really , you would n't believe how often we have discussed this question — would he , Julia , dear ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But I am never going to grant your wish , Pierre , dear . You shall keep your liberty — you shall be free ! Even as I ask nothing better than to follow my own inclinations . If I am ruined because of them — well , it 's no one 's concern but my own — no one 's !Tosses her head .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: May I inquire what those inclinations are ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: It 's hard to say — off-hand .— You must feel it — you must — Well , I want to be free !— I want to hold my fate in my own hands !— I want — Oh , why talk about it ? What is one poor , human life ?— especially a life like mine !— I am branded — doomed to the gutter !— One need use no ceremony with me now !

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Really ! Well — h 'm — if I had known that you felt that way about it — I should have made you — a different proposition — Julia , dear .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Tell me ! Please !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Yes — tell us — please !

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: I suppose I may assume that the people at the castle know nothing of this little adventure of the young Count 's ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: You may rest assured , my dear sir , that I know what is due a woman 's honour .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Ah — really !— Well , I 'm sure no one saw me coming here . So then , there need be no scandal .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: That would certainly be most agreeable to all parties concerned .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: But — how did the lady propose to leave here without being seen ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Pray , my dear sir , let that be my concern .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: That concern , however , I shall share with you — my dear sir . And it seems to me that the best plan would be for the lady to put on a decent dress , walk through the grounds with me , and pay a visit to the Countess at the castle .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: What !— my mother —? What 's the use of that ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: It will look as if she 'd returned — and we 'd — somehow — met here .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Do you think any one is going to believe that ? WittichproudlyWhat else should they believe ? Juliafrightened anewOh , but I do n't want to ! I do n't want to do that ! Pierre ! I want to stay with you ! I am under your protection , Pierre !

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: See here , my dear sir , let us suppose that your plan is successful — what then ?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Yes — yes — afterward — what then ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Then ?— Then —Looks from one to the other , uncertainly , almost imploringly , and breaks down again .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Well — wo n't you go on with your proposition ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Yes , I suppose that when a man has acted as I have acted here , he must have lost — his sense of pride — and honour — and all the rest of it — long ago .— Then nothing is left him but — his duty .— And the thing that seems to me my — duty — I am going to do .— Let the Count sneer at me — I no longer ——

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh , please — I say !

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Well , then , let me tell you something , Julia . After I had read the letter from Brussels , I had two rooms prepared for you — in the left wing — quite apart ; so that some day , in case — you ever — came back — Oh , well — it does n't matter now . But the rooms — are — still there — and if you would like to come home with me now — straight off — well , you might be spared — some annoyance .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: H 'm — so you 're willing —?Shrugs his shoulders and laughs .I suppose that sort of thing is all a matter of taste — but I can understand ——

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: I am speaking to you , Julia .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Oh , I thank you most heartily , George . It 's certainly very noble of you — and — I deeply appreciate it . But after — this , I should always feel ashamed before you — I should feel that I was just being tolerated — I — No . Thank you , George — but I could n't stand it . Pierrecorrecting herThat is —!Aside to Julia .Do n't be a fool ! Wittichwithout noticing PierreYou shall never hear a word of reproach from my lips , Julia , dear .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: But — if I should actually accept — we never could go on as we did before , you know . I must be free to do exactly as I please — to go away — come back — just as I like . There is such a thing as the sovereignty of the individuality , my dear George — you can n't deny that .

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Herr Wittich can n't possibly deny that !

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: You shall have your own way as far as it lies in my power , Julia , dear .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And then , you must try to bring a little more — more beauty into our life .— I surely have the right to demand that . Just look about you here . You know how passionately fond of roses I am . My soul demands something besides — potatoes ! Well , I insist upon having roses around me . That 's not unreasonable , is it ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: You shall have roses enough to smother you . PierrenervouslyWell , then , Julia , dear , I see no reason why we should not accept this proposition .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: What have you got to say about it ?

lg.l: I beg your pardon , Herr Wittich . I certainly do n't want to offend you .
But — as Julia and I have found so much in each other — have n't we ,

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Yes — so very , very much , Pierre , dear .— And to know that we were so near — and yet could never see each other or talk together , or — I , for my part , could n't endure it , could you , Pierre ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Oh — as for that — well , it would be hard , Julia , dear .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: And what would the world say , dear George , if we should suddenly — and apparently without any cause — break off all communication with our neighbors ? How would Pierre explain it to his mother ? Why , he simply could n't ! No ; if we are to carry out your plan , then everything must remain outwardly the same as before . Do n't you agree with me , Pierre , dear ?

sp.speaker: Pierre
sp.p: Hesitating , with an apprehensive glance toward Wittich .Outwardly — yes , Julia , dear . Wittichlosing control of himselfSo that 's your condition , is it ? Juliawith a sort of nervous impudenceYes , that 's our condition — is n't it , Pierre , dear ?Pierre does not reply , but looks at Wittich .

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: Really ?— Really !— Very well !He draws himself to his full height , his face flushes , and he looks around the room wildly , as if searching for something .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: What are you looking for , George ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: If you —Gasps as if suffocating .

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: George ! George ! What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: Wittich
sp.p: There — there — there !With a loud cry , he falls upon the weapons and snatches one of the daggers .

sp.speaker: Julia

sp.speaker: MARGOT
sp.p: The richly furnished office of a prosperous lawyer . Pictures , bronzes , carved furniture , costly hangings . In the foreground , on the left , a window ; turned toward it , a writing-table with a writing-chair behind . Near the window , a leather arm-chair . At the narrow side of the table , in the foreground , a low seat . On the right , a sofa , table , and chairs . In the background , a door which , when opened , reveals the clerks working at long tables . To the right , back , another door . The backward projection of the writing-table forms a revolving-stand for reference books . On the writing-table , among documents and writing materials , are photographs in standing frames and a slender vase filled with dark red roses . It is winter , about six o'clock in the evening . The lamps are lighted . Ebeling is seated in the writing-chair . He is a man of about forty , attractive , winning in manner , his clothes betokening wealth and refinement ; he wears a short , dark beard , and his hair is slightly gray at the temples . Von Tietz , sitting opposite him in the arm-chair , is about thirty , very smartly dressed — in appearance a type of the ordinary drawing-room devotee . Ebelingholding out a box of cigarsThere ! Now let 's chat . Will you smoke ? v. Tietzhelping himselfReally now — if I 'm disturbing you ——

sp.p: Is any one still there ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Yes , I know . Well , let me have the papers .Bonath lays them before him .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: To v. Tietz .You can go on speaking . These are only signatures .— Have you a light ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: See that this decision is delivered to Baron von Kanoldt at once .

sp.speaker: Bonath
sp.p: Yes , Herr Ebeling .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: You 've become a collector , I see . EbelingsigningOne must have some diversion .

sp.p: What 's that ? Looks like a Terburg . Is it an original ? EbelingsigningWould you expect it to be a copy ?

sp.speaker: v. Tietz

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Then you can announce Frau von Yburg as soon as she comes .v. Tietz listens attentively .

sp.speaker: Bonath
sp.p: Very well , Herr Ebeling .Goes out .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: The lady you are expecting is Frau von Yburg ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Of course you know that I 've been the Yburg 's legal adviser for years . v. Tietzsitting downWell , really , this is quite a marvellous coincidence . It 's on account of the Yburgs that I 've come to see you . EbelinginterestedIs that so ? What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: My dear friend , if you had n't so completely drawn away from all society since your wife l ——alarmed .I beg your pardon .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Go on ! Say it ! Left me ! Walked out of the house ! You may say it . But then — drop it ! Even our old fraternity friendship does n't oblige us to be everlastingly putting each other on the grill .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: No , really — it escaped me somehow . I 'm awfully sorry .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Oh , well , never mind . You know , I speak of it quite disinterestedly . And it 's a good many years since then . Only — I 'd rather not be attacked unawares .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Do n't worry . I 'll be on my guard . But — as we 've mentioned it — there 's something I wanted to ask you before — only I had n't the courage . Tell me , do you always keep her picture on your table ? Ebelingin a hard voice

sp.speaker: Yes
sp.p: v. Tietz . Then you still love her ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: No . I only keep the picture there to warn me against making a fool of myself again . So many charming women sit there where you 're sitting , women just on the point of divorce — and therefore in need of consolation . Every now and then one of them undertakes to faint — um — and then I have to —Holds out his arms .v. Tietzbursting out laughingAha ! Very interesting ! Very interesting !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: In short , it does no harm to keep the picture there .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Of course , everyone knows how much courted you are . For instance , no matter when I come to see you , I always find those beautiful roses on your table . They speak for themselves . Heavens ! What a luxury ! Roses in January !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Things like that come anonymously . If I knew who the sender was , I would n't accept them .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Let me with all due modesty give you a piece of advice : you ought to marry .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Ironically , shaking his finger at him across the table .Thank you . But did n't you want to speak to me about the Yburgs ?

sp.speaker: V. Tietz
sp.p: Yes . What was I going to say ?— Oh , yes . Well , if you had n't taken it into your head to live like a hermit , you 'd know that , for some time past , I 've been a very frequent visitor at the Yburgs 's .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Oh , yes , I know . I go there myself sometimes — only not when other people are around .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Well , then , to make a long story short — why should I mince matters with you ?— I am courting Margot . EbelingstartledAh — you , too ? You 're also one of the crowd ? v. TietzconceitedlyI trust that I stand up a bit above the crowd .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Indeed ? I thought perhaps the social glamour of the Yburgs was attracting you . A thing like that can n't help dazzling one . But that you ——

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Is it so surprising ? That girl is so bewitching — so — so entirely unlike these forward , city-bred girls . With her , at least , one knows what one can count on . She 's so — so the essence of everything innocent and chaste and pure . Ebelingquoting“ Be thou as chaste as ice , as pure as snow , ” — thy dowry shall not escape me .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: No , no — do n't joke . It 's out of place . I wo n't deny that , as an official without fortune — that would also be very — h 'm — but ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Yes , but what have I got to do with it ?

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: See here , my dear friend , we scattered remnants of the old college fraternity have grown so accustomed to ask your help in times of need , to look up to you as a sort of father confessor ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Do you want me to go and propose for you ?

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: We 'll talk of that later . But first I 'd like to ask you something . See here , what role is Baron von Kanoldt playing in this family ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: So that 's it !

sp.speaker: V. Tietz
sp.p: You 're his counsel in his divorce proceedings , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: As the affair has become common talk , I need make no secret of it .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: They say that it is the wife who has been the martyr . And yet , after fifteen years , he begins the divorce proceedings . Why should he ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: My dear fellow , you must put that question to some one who 's not so well informed as I am .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Oh , see here , I do n't want to be indiscreet about it , but the further the case goes , the more persistent are the rumours that he has designs on Margot 's hand — and , furthermore , that her mother is encouraging him !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Frau von Yburg will be here in a few minutes .— Ask her !

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: What do you take me for ? Ebelingshrugging his shouldersOh , well then ——

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: But just think ! that man — forty , if he 's a day , fat , worn out , a roue whose amorous adventures are common gossip to every cabby on the street !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Pardon me , my clients are all virtuous , young , handsome , desirable — of inestimable pulchritude .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: See here — are you chaffing me ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I 'm only trying to make you understand that you 've unwittingly walked into the enemy 's camp . v. Tietzstanding upVery well — if you do n't want to ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Also stands up , and puts his hand on v. Tietz 's shoulder .My dear fellow , you 're ten years younger than I . You 're one of your country 's young hopefuls . Go ahead and do what your heart and pocket-book bid you .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: I did n't need you to tell me that .A knock at the door .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Come in .

sp.speaker: Bonath
sp.p: Frau von Yburg and ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling

Yburg is a woman of about forty , dressed simply but tastefully ; her bearing is dignified , self-possessed , refined , and betrays a natural , unaffected knowledge of the demands of convention ; but hidden behind her assurance , and scarcely noticeable , are the traces of an old sorrow , a helpless glance , and a forced smile . Margot is a lovely young girl , extremely well-bred , with a somewhat shy , reserved manner .v. Tietzat sight of Margot

sp.speaker: Ah !
sp.p: Frau v. Yburg . I brought my little girl along , Herr Ebeling , to let her catch a glimpse of the lion 's den . I hope that you wo n't mind . Ebelingkissing her handA thousand times welcome , dear ladies .Shakes hands with Margot .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: I 'm very happy to meet you both — I had n't hoped to see Fraeulein Yburg here . But our friend believes in military promptitude . I have just received permission to take my leave .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: I hope that you will come to see us soon , Herr von Tietz .

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: That 's very kind of you .Bowing to Margot .Fraeulein Yburg ! Ebelingaccompanying him to the doorGood-bye , my dear fellow . No bad feelings now ——

sp.speaker: v. Tietz
sp.p: Oh , I say ! Of course not !Goes out .

sp.p: Wo n't you sit down ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Oh , no . Margot is only going to glance around a bit . Yes , my little girl , you may well look about . Between these four walls many a fate has been shaped .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Let us rather say , has been mended . Margotsoftly , suddenly looking up

sp.speaker: Mine , too ?
sp.p: Frau v. Yburg .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: It will give me great pleasure .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Then run away , dear , pay your visit , and let the carriage bring you back again .Sits down , right .

sp.p: Giving him her hand with social assurance , but a little timidly , none the less .Au revoir , Herr Ebeling .

sp.p: Au revoir , Fraeulein Margot .Accompanies her to the door , and calls .Bonath , see to it that Fraeulein Yburg finds her way out . She is coming back later . Voice of Bonath . Very well , Herr Ebeling .
