sp.p: Well , Frau von Yburg , we 've brought matters to this point .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: sighingYes .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: The divorce was granted yesterday morning .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Yes , I know .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Well , are n't you pleased ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: My dear Herr Ebeling , my heart is so full of gratitude — really , I do n't know how to thank you — for myself and also for my poor , dear child . But I 'm so helpless — so perplexed — I really do n't know — I ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Why , what can be wrong ?

lg.l: Yes — just fancy — well , then — she wo n't do it !

sp.speaker: What 's that ?
sp.p: Frau v. Yburg . Think of the monstrosity of it ! She wo n't do it .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Has she been notified that the divorce has been granted ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Yesterday — just after the proceedings — Baron von Kanoldt — came — with his proposal .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: H 'm !— quicker than I had expected .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: My husband , of course , was simply thunderstruck . One can surely sympathise with him — von Kanoldt — a man in the forties — divorced — with grown children — and such a reputation ! But when he saw that I took the man 's part — I had to do that , did n't I ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: That was our only course .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Then his position , his wealth , his connections at court — oh , yes , and naturally our long friendship — Of course , my husband does n't surmise what this man did to her ! In the end , he agreed that Margot herself should decide .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Well , and —? What ——?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: She came , looked him quietly in the face , and asked for time to think it over .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: It seems to me your husband was very clever . Otherwise , he might perhaps have ——

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Yes , but when we were alone , just fancy ! she declared quite simply : “ No , I wo n't do it . ” I exclaimed , “ Why , my dear child , you 're out of your mind ! You know that we 've done everything for the sake of this day ! ” “ Yes , I know all about it — but I wo n't . ” “ You 've been wishing it for three years , ” I said to her . And what do you suppose she answered ! “ I never wished it . You talked it into me — and he . ”

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: “ He ? ” Pardon me , who ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: You , Herr Ebeling . Ebelingstanding up in his excitementMy dear lady , it was my duty to carry out what you and Fraeulein Margot desired — and what , in short , the circumstances demanded .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Oh , I know ! My God , how well I realise it ! And what a task you 've accomplished ! No — when I remember how much persuasion , how much subtle reasoning , how much — Ah , and how I 've suffered these three years ! See , my hair is quite gray !— And I still can n't understand it ! I still look upon the girl as if she were a stranger , a mysterious being who has lost her way and accidentally come to me . I — I who was brought up so strictly , watched , and carefully tended all my life , kept worlds away from any taint of the unconventional — And she , too — No , on that point , I can n't reproach myself . And yet — this horror ! No , I shall never , never understand it ! Ah , and to have to bear it all alone ! Oh , yes , I had to do that . My husband , with his long army training , would have forced him to fight — and then we should all have been dragged in the dust . Margot 's life — our position in society — everything ! Ah , if you had n't been here , Herr Ebeling ! Do you remember how I came to you ? I think I was half dead from wretchedness ! With the letter to him in my hand , the letter that I had taken from her as she lay distracted in my arms ! Do you remember ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Oh , do n't speak of it ! As I read that handwriting — still so childish — and that helpless , stammering question : “ What has happened to me ? ” — God knows , everything turned black before my eyes ! Oh ! it 's too horrible !

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: And then you yourself said to me , “ You 're right — the blackguard must . I 'll make him . ”

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I said it in the heat of the first great indignation . Please take that into consideration . After I went to work , I religiously kept to my programme to leave all threats and violence out of the question . Not only because — Ah , as I 've come to feel now , such a calm method of procedure would be impossible . But then I had to keep in mind that a new life — I do n't venture to say a happy one — was to be gained through me . To-day , some one is grateful to me — the very one who at first opposed me most violently — that poor , wretched wife .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: And now everything would have been forgiven . I can n't understand it . I do n't know — I ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: So she wo n't do it ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: And that 's why I 've fled to you in my need ! Later , when she returns , I want to have gone . You understand ? I 've arranged it this way so that you could bring her to her senses . A little heart to heart talk , you know . But if your influence does n't help , then I do n't know — then —— Ebelingwalking up and downAnd so she wo n't do it .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Yes , just explain it to me ! The only possible way in which to rehabilitate herself in her own eyes ! And she throws it to the winds ! What can she be thinking of ? What ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: And so she wo n't do it !

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: What 's come over you , Herr Ebeling ? You 're not listening ! Ebelingfirmly , quietlyVery well , then she shall not .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: For God 's sake ! You , too ! You , too , want ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: My dear friend , I have done all that lay in my power , often against my own convictions , I can assure you . She knows what she is doing . She will not . Very well . I 'm not here to bait her to her ruin . I am very sorry , but this time I must refuse my assistance .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: But what will happen ? Must all our work count for nothing — your work , my work ? For I have worked over her with all my powers , I need not hesitate to say it , worked to place her again on those spiritual heights where a young girl of family by right belongs . I have led her back to Religion , for whoever has anything to expiate must possess Religion . I have read with her only the most carefully selected books , books that could never , never endanger a young girl 's imagination . And I have taken special care to see to it that when she was in the company of young people , she should , if possible , be stricter and even more reserved than the most timid of her friends . For her need of such behaviour was double theirs , was n't it ? And you yourself will admit that my efforts have been successful . No one could deny it and look into those clear , steadfast eyes of hers .Ebeling nods assent .She has become all soul — all —— Ebelingdoubtingly , sadly

sp.speaker: Ah !
sp.p: Frau v. Yburg . Yes , indeed , Herr Ebeling . No clandestine , no unseemly wish finds its way into her heart . I 'll vouch for that . She glides through life like a silent spirit , cleansed and purified .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: And therefore we are to throw her into the jaws of that beast .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Is there any other way ? Do you know of any ? EbelingtormentedH 'm ! She certainly has suitors enough !

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: She 'll reject them all — as she has heretofore . She simply says , “ I shall not begin my new life with a lie . I think too much of myself for that . And to confess , to tell the man , and have him turn his back on me , or out of pure pity raise me to his own level — I think entirely too much of myself for that . ”

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I believe one can readily appreciate her feelings .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: But what will become of her ? Is she to wither and wear away — this heavenly young creature ?Ebeling walks about , growing more and more excited . A pause .Herr Ebeling , speak ! Advise me ! EbelingfirmlyI know of only one solution : she must choose some one who knows it .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Who could that be — except ——? Ebelingbreathing heavilyExcept that man , there is only one other .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Stares at him uncomprehendingly with her hands clasped , then stammering .Oh ! oh , God ! What a joy that would be !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: What more can I say ? Such things come and grow great in a man , one knows not how . She bore her sorrow , her shame , I mine . At first , perhaps , it was no more than a casual fancy — no , an interest , for my inclinations were always involved — but to-day it has become a passion , a passion that , lonely man as I am , gnaws me to the very core of my being .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: But how have you managed through it all to keep so quiet , so deliberate , so ——?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: One learns , little by little , to be master of oneself . And five minutes ago there was absolutely no hope ,bursting outbut if she no longer wants him — why should n't I — oh !Hides his face in his hand , trembling with emotion .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Wait ! I do n't see , after you 've led him on to this point , how you 'll ever justify all this to Baron von Kanoldt .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I do n't know ! Until now , I 've led a tolerably respectable life . For , in the disgrace that shepointing to the picture of his wifebrought upon me , I played no part .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Oh , yes , everyone in society knows that .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: But I have n't once asked myself whether what I am now going to do — or should like to do — conforms to the prevailing standards of propriety . One ought to think it over , to let some time elapse — in short , I do n't know ! All I can say is that if she does n't want him , if she wo n't take that —checking himself— him , well , then , the path is open to any one — to me as well as to another .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: hesitatingI feel that I ought to warn you of just one thing more . She has never seemed to consider you as anything more than a fatherly sort of friend .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: H 'm !Laughs bitterly .Even though I 'm a couple of years younger than ——, I 've certainly acted more like a father to her . But you 're probably right .Knocking .Come in .Bonath enters .

sp.speaker: Bonath
sp.p: I 've let the clerks go home . Have you any further orders , Herr Ebeling ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: You can go , too , Bonath . But tell my man to answer the door .

sp.speaker: Bonath
sp.p: Very well , Herr Ebeling . Good evening .Bonath goes out .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Frau von Yburg , your daughter will return in a few minutes . Meanwhile , the scene has changed not altogether insignificantly . Do you still approve of that little private heart to heart talk — or not ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: Ah , my dear friend , I have such boundless confidence in you . You 've been her good angel for so long . I do n't hesitate for a moment to leave her in your hands . And you 'll carefully observe all the conventions ? Of course you will .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: But what can I say to her ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: You 're so skilled in reading the heart . You 'll have found a way to make her confess something before she 's aware of it . Only let me beg of you — if you find nothing in what she says that gives you reason to hope , then please do n't worry her . She has already suffered so much .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Very well , then , I 'll proceed upon the assumption that I have only to comply with the request that brought you to me to-day .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: If you would ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Hush !Listens at the door , then pointing to the right .May I ask you to go out this door ? You know your way .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Yburg
sp.p: And please , please , spare her delicacy . You 've no idea how pure she is — in spite of ——

lg.l: If I did n't know that —
lg.stage: Knocking . He opens the door , right .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Come in .

sp.speaker: The Servant
sp.p: A young lady is outside . She wants to know whether her mother is still here .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Hurrying to the centre door — vivaciously .Just fancy Fraeulein Margot , your mother thought you 'd no longer be coming , and has only just left .Margot appears at the centre door , and stands there , hesitating .But wo n't you come in for a few moments ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Gladly , if I may .Looking about irresolutely .Only I do n't know whether I ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: What , my dear child ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: It is n't usually mamma 's way to go off without me .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Then I 'll take you home myself . You need have no fears .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Oh , I 'm not afraid . Ebelinginviting her to sit down

sp.speaker: Wo n't you ——?
sp.p: Margot . I 'd like to look around a bit first ; may I ? I could n't a while ago .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I 'm only too happy to think that you take some interest in my home .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Dear me , mamma has so often told me about it . Of late years her visits to you were our principal topic of conversation . I think I 've known every tiny nook here for a long , long time .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Really ?

lg.l: Oh , there 's the stand with the horrible law books !
Herr Ebeling , everything in life is Law — and everything is in books .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: My dear young girl , the hardest laws are never to be found in books .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Yes , you are right . The laws that drag us down to destruction are the laws that we make for ourselves . And all those beautiful women ! I suppose one must be very beautiful to join them ? Ebelingparrying lightlyMost of them are clients who have presented me with their pictures as a token of gratitude .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Well , but I 'm your client , too — and yet I should never dare to offer you my picture in that way .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Yes , that 's my former wife .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I saw her only once in my life . I was a mere child then . She was very lovely .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Yes , she was lovely .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Oh , and the wonder — wonderful roses ! Mamma has told me that you always have such lovely roses . EbelinglightlyYes , I have an agreement with a gardener . He keeps me supplied . Margotseemingly convinced

sp.speaker: Oh !
sp.p: Ebeling . May I present them to you , Fraeulein Margot ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Oh , dear me , no . The gardener who keeps you supplied might be offended . Ebelinglaughing

sp.speaker: As you wish
sp.p: Margot . And this is the inquisitional chair — where the poor secrets are dragged out ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Quite the contrary ! The secrets come forth of their own accord . I always have to say “ stop . ”

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Well , then , I need n't hesitate to sit down .Does so .My secret you know —sighing— only too well !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: My dear Fraeulein Margot ; the real secret of your life , the law that governs your thoughts and feelings , I believe no one knows — not even your mother . Margotsmiling and shrugging her shouldersMy good mamma ! And I 'm here to give you proofs of that fact , am I ? Ebelingevasively

sp.speaker: Oh !
sp.p: Margot . The reason for my being here is n't the one you 've given me .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Indeed ! What is it ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I was n't left here alone for nothing ! Please go ahead , Herr Ebeling , do your duty and talk me nicely into marrying Baron von —shuddersSee ?— I 've never once been able to bring his name to my lips . And yet I 'm to pass my whole life with that man ! Can one picture anything more horrible ?Shudders again .Do you know of any occupation for me , Herr Ebeling ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Occupation ? Why ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I want to leave home .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Is that your earnest intention ? MargotnodsBut , unfortunately , I 've learned nothing . And then — it has to be an occupation that would n't humiliate me — and that would n't spoil my handstakes off her gloves, for I love my hands . I do n't care a bit about my face , but my hands — they 're like two friends . I can keep up long conversations with them — especially with the left . That one 's so weak . So , something that would n't spoil the hands — and would leave me time for reading — and — well , I want to be alone .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I might have suggested nursing , even though it requires the constant use of the hands . But , of course , you 'd never be alone .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: No . I have no love for my fellow-creatures . I do n't want to do anything for them .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Those are hard words , Fraeulein Margot .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I am hard . What have my fellow-creatures ever done for me ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: And — your parents ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: You refer to mamma ? Mamma certainly means well . But mamma has torn my soul from my body . She has made use of the old principle of family rule — which may have had some sense in the Stone Age — and has turned me into a doll , a doll-creature that moves its eyes and says ba when you press its head .— Just watch , Herr Ebeling !— Now have n't I a touching fashion of casting up my eyes when I look at you in this simple , thoughtful , innocent way ?— And when I let the lids fall again in all the bashful piety that I still can muster — is n't it simply sweet ? EbelingearnestlyMy dear young girl , I really believe I must begin to say “ stop ” now !

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Dear me ! You 're already disgusted with me ! But if you had any idea — do you know what you 'd think ? “ Pity that I wasted such pains on a creature like her ! ”

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I should never think that , my dear child . I should only pity you and love you the more .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I do n't want to be pitied ! And loved ?Shakes her head .At least not that way — and not the other , either . That 's still stupider . When I listen to my friends — this one loves me , and that one loves me , and this one kept my glove , and that one kissed my handkerchief — ugh ! It reminds me of the cackling of a lot of hens . Herr Ebeling , do you believe criminals are scornful ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Why do you ask ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Please answer .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: It 's very often true of born criminals .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Well , then , I 've the criminal nature . Ebelinglaughing against his willTut , tut , my dear child , why so — all of a sudden ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Because I inwardly shrug my shoulders at everything that goes by the name of Innocence . I keep thinking to myself , “ You silly sheep , what do you know about it ? ” — Ah , and yet , I envy them ! At the balls , I see everything as through a veil . The things that the men chatter about sound far , far away — oceans off . I always feel like saying , “ Do n't trouble about me . Go to that girl over there . She 's stupid enough . ” And then — after I 've come home — I weep , weep from sheer envy and utter boredom , weep until I have to turn my pillow .— And mamma ? Mamma drags me from ball to ball : I must n't be unlike the others , you know !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: My dear child , if this goes against your nature , why do n't you make some resistance ? Why do n't you show your mother that you have thoughts and feelings of your own which must be respected ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Ah , my dear Herr Ebeling , just be a whipped dog yourself , year in year out ! The dog does n't resist either — but suddenly , some day — when he 's at the very end of his endurance — he bites his master 's hand . I shall bite soon !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Oh , I 'll grant you that your mother has probably made some mistakes . But only out of love , or because she knew no better . Just ask yourself what would have become of you if you 'd been left to yourself all this time ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I should have been embittered just the same — you 're right — but I should not have let myself fall .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Who knows ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Never ! And I 'll tell you something to prove it . Severely as I have been watched — and — surely there 's nothing coquettish about me ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Certainly not .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: You can believe me when I say that , in the general moral tone prevailing over our society just now — and of which our mothers naturally know nothing — there lurks a temptation which has over and over again enticed even me . Such things are so personal , so secret — one cannot describe them . Oh , I could have done whatever I wished ! But I said to myself : the first time , you were ignorant , you were sacrificed — or , at least , you can talk it into yourself that you were sacrificed — but if ever again — no , I can n't say it after all !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I understand , my child .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: If ever again — then you 'll be lost — forever ! Then there can be no more ideals , no more poetry — nothing lofty — nothing for which to work — and , worst of all , nothing of which to dream . For to dream — ah , one must dream , must n't one ? When one no longer has that !—— EbelingmovedYes , dear child .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: But you must n't think that I 'm trying to make myself interesting , or that I stand here before you beautifully whitened and purified ! Oh , no ! What I 'm going to say to you now has never been said to any one , to any man before . And you are going to despise me utterly . But I must say it — once , once in my life — and then the old hypocrisy can go on again . Well , I do n't know what it is , but it 's like a fire in me . No , worse , much worse ! When I think of that frightful man , my heart fairly shrivels up . And yet — I can never get away from it . There 's always a terror , a horror in me ; and yet there is always an eternal — an eternal hunger . Yes — a restlessness — a search — the whole day long . It 's strongest toward twilight . Then I want to go out — out into the wide world — to fly to unknown lands . Then I think to myself — out there , no one knows you ; out there , there is no sin . Ah , it 's as if I were lashed ! And I heap such reproaches upon myself because of it ! Even now you have not heard the worst . I must tell you the worst , too . Well , you know how I hate that man — yet , sometimes it seems to me that I must go to him and say to him — Behold , here I am again ! Ebelingjumps up , muttering to himselfWhat has he done ? The scoundrel ! The blackguard !

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: There ! Now you know on whom you 've wasted your sympathy ! Now I can go .Stands up , snatches her muff , and prepares to leave .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Who has been silently walking up and down more hotly .It appears then that you still love that man . Margotwith a short , cutting laughOh , Herr Ebeling , if you 've gathered that from all I 've said , then I might just as well have addressed myself to the four walls . I 've been hoping for three long years that you would secretly manage the thing in such a way that I 'd never have to see him again in all my life — never , never — not even from a distance .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Why did you never confide in me before ? Why to-day for the first time ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Can one do such a thing ? Is one ever allowed to ? I 'm a well-bred young girl , you know . I must observe the conventions . How I came to do it to-day , I do n't know myself . But formerly when you were alone with me , did you ever , at any time , give me to understand , even by a glance , that you — you knew anything — about me ? Do you think such an attitude gives one courage ? Ah , and in my need I 've prayed so often , “ Dear God , let him see into my soul ! If he does n't free me , no one will . ” Instead , you 've only plunged me the deeper — pushed me before you — always deeper into misery — into the arms of that beast — into the filth .Sinks into a chair , sobbing .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Regards her confusedly , then approaches her .Dear child ! That was n't my intention !Laying his hand on her shoulder caressingly .My dear , dear child !

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Grasps his hand , and presses her cheek to it . As he tries to free it , she holds it the more closely .Oh , do n't leave me . I 'm so lonely !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: My dear , dear child .He bends down to her and kisses her on the brow . She throws her arms about his neck and draws herself close to him . He kisses her lips . She lets her head fall heavily upon his shoulder and remains motionless while he caresses her gently . With a sudden impulse she flings him from her , and sinks back in the chair .Margot , my darling . Have I hurt you ? Are you offended at what I did ? If I 've misunderstood , if I have abused your confidence , I earnestly beg you to forgive me .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Oh , I 've so hungered — so hungered — for this — kiss ! Ebelingturning eagerly toward her

sp.speaker: Margot !
sp.p: Margotwarding him offNo ! Go away ! Go away !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: But you do n't refuse me ? And I 'm not too old ? Margotpassionately bursting into laughter

sp.speaker: Oh !
sp.p: Ebeling . I was never free from the fear that you might not see anything in me except an image of that wasted , old creature .Instead of answering , Margot stretches out her arms to him with a soft cry of longing . Ebeling draws the low stool to the writing-chair on which she is sitting , sits down upon it , and embraces her .Margot , my youth , my whole youth that I 've squandered and frittered away comes back to me once more through you . And now all will be well with you , too . It was only a nightmare . Your true self had nothing to do with it . Only — you must take heart again — you must think of yourself now . MargotecstaticallyYes , I am equal to anything now . I am not afraid to face the worst . I can even marry that man . I shall send him my acceptance quite calmly .— Of course . Why not ? Ebelingshocked

sp.speaker: What !
sp.p: Margot . Why should you be astonished at that ? Now that I know you love me ? Only for a year ! Perhaps for two ! Yes , two ! Oh , please , two ! Then , later , when you 've left me , let others come ! It 's all the same , who ! For marriage , of course , I 'm entirely spoiled ! But I 'll be revenged on him ! On him and on Virtue and on Loyalty and on all that stuff with which they 've so long tormented me . And the evening before my wedding — then may I — come to you again ? Toward twilight ! It must be on a Sunday . I 'll arrange for that , so we can be alone . Ah , I shall count the days till then ! Why do you look at me like that ?Ebeling stands up and throws himself on the sofa , burying his face in his hands . A long pause .What can I have done ?She stands up . Another pause .Surely I have n't done you any wrong by loving you ?

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Go home now , my child .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I wanted to leave some time ago , but you made me stay .She buttons her coat , throws on her boa , and is about to go out . Then she turns around resolutely , and places herself before him .Oh , I know — I 'm disgraced — I 'm not worthy of anything better —; but I need n't have had to endure such scorn and contempt !Ebeling rises , looks at her , groans , buries his face in his hands , and falls back into the chair . Margot kneels beside him , weeping .Dear — dearest — what is it ? What 's wrong , my darling ? Ebelingcompelling himself to be composedStand up !She does so .I am going to tell you .Stands up himself .I asked your mother 's consent to my marrying you to-day . There , now you know it . Good-bye .Sits down in the writing-chair . A pause .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Does not move . Her face becomes hard and bitter .And now that you see what sort I am —— H 'm , yes . Ah , well , you 'll soon console yourself . There are so many others . Why should it be just I ? Let me suggest one of my friends — a dear — a pretty girl — with white teeth . Why take it to heart ? It hurts for the moment — but one easily forgets . Such girls as I deserve nothing better . To them — one does this !Plucks the petals from the roses which are standing before her in the vase .And then one throws them away — like this !Throws the petals in his face .Ebelingbrushing away the petalsWhat have the roses done to you , my child ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: I sent them to you . I , too , may destroy them . Ebelingspringing upIt was you , you who all these years ——?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Good evening , Herr Ebeling .She goes out .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Pauses for a moment irresolutely , struggling with himself , then hurries after her . His voice is heard .Stay here ! Stay here ! Come in here !He reappears at the centre door , pulling her by the arm .Come in here ! Come back !

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: What do you want of me ? I 'll cry for help ——

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Come here !Drags her to the writing-table .

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Leave me alone !

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: Be quiet ! Be quiet !Picks up one of the pictures standing on the table .There ! That woman dragged my name in the gutter . Will you do the same ? Answer me !Margot stands motionless , the tears running down her cheeks .Answer , I say . Margotslowly and heavilyAh , one thinks and says so much when there 's no longer a particle of hope in one 's life .

sp.speaker: Ebeling
sp.p: I understand .He throws the picture on the ground ; frame and glass are dashed to pieces .Let us go to your parents . We 'll arrange with them what 's best to be done .As she does n't move .Well ?Margot shakes her head .You do n't want to ?

sp.speaker: Margot
sp.p: Not that way ! As I am now , humiliated — mortified — disgraced — no , not that way ! I am so tired of playing Magdalen ! No ! When I come , I 'll come with a free step . I 'll be able to look every man in the face ! But I must find out first what I am still worth , andlooking him full in the faceit must be a great , great deal — to be worthy of you . EbelingmovedGive me your hands , dear . Margotdoing soWhen we see each other again , they 'll be red and ugly .Ebeling kisses her hands and presses them to his face .Good-bye .She turns to go .

sp.speaker: CHARACTERS
sp.p: The Unknown Lady . Lieutenant Von Wolters . Mulbridge , a horse-trainer . His Wife . Daisy , their daughter . Kellermann . Tempski , an orderly . A Groom . The Present Day . The scene is laid in a large German garrison .

sp.speaker: THE LAST VISIT
sp.p: Frau Mulbridge . Well , now we have seen our poor , dear captain for the last time .

sp.speaker: Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes . He was a good fellow , our captain and — awfully fond of horses .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Why , Daisy , what 's the matter , dear ? You 've been standing here all alone , and yet , until now , you would n't stir from the coffin .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I saw him quite well from here , mother , dear . Mulbridgecaressing herMy girlie — my little girl . Yes — we all loved him .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: To Tempski , who is sobbing .There , there , Tempski , hush now .A bell rings , right .There 's the bell ; go and open the door .Tempski goes out at the right .Mulbridgeto the GroomAnd we 'll be off to the stables !

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Sh ! The Lieutenant ! Mulbridgeto the GroomGo on !Pushes the Groom out , left .

body.stage: Lieutenant von Wolters enters . He is an attractive young officer , very smart in appearance , wearing the uniform of an Uhlan . Kellermann , a self-possessed , sharp-eyed man , follows him . While they are entering , Tempski comes in at the right , quietly places a wreath on one of the piles near the columns , and goes out again .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Well , Herr —He puts his hand to his eyes , overcome for the moment , then stiffly , trying to conceal his emotion .Herr — Kellermann was the name , was n't it ?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: At your service , Lieutenant .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: You have done everything very satisfactorily . I am much obliged to you . You understand that the removal of the coffin to the church is to be accomplished as secretly as possible .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: I 'm silent as the grave , Lieutenant . My business sort of carries that with it , do n't you know .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: It will be dark about half past five . I have ordered the troops that are to accompany the casket to be here at half past six . At the church — the catafalque and the rest — I can confidently leave all that to you ?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Most assuredly , Lieutenant . I shall see that everything is of the finest .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: But remember your instructions : all superfluous ostentation is to be rigorously avoided — to-morrow at the funeral procession , also .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: I understand , Lieutenant — because of the way he met his death .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: The reason does not concern you .Turns to go .

sp.speaker: Mulbridge
sp.p: Beg pardon , Lieutenant , but may I speak to you ? I 've been in the captain 's service seven years . I 've been in Germany nearly eighteen years — have a German wife and daughter . I 'm not as young as I used to be . What 's going to become of the horses and the racing-stable , and — the rest ?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes , it 's really too bad about him , Lieutenant . He 's so fond of his horses . Why , if ever you want to speak to him , you have to go and stay at the stable . That 's the only way I can manage to see him .

sp.speaker: Mulbridge
sp.p: And she 's a great help to me , too , Lieutenant .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I can understand your anxiety , Mulbridge . The captain spoke about you on our last journey together . He especially commended you and your family to my care . But , of course , everything will depend upon the heir .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: And who is the heir , Lieutenant ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: No one knows . He had no relatives . But be assured that whoever it is , I will do my best to ——

sp.speaker: Mulbridge
sp.p: Thank you , Lieutenant ! Thank you !He says a few words aside to his wife and goes out , left .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Have you anything else to do here , Herr Kellermann ?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Yes , indeed , a great many things , Lieutenant .Goes out at the centre , carrying several wreaths , and then returns for more . Frau Mulbridge helps him .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Oh , by the way , may I have a word with you , Daisy ?Daisy comes forward , v. Wolters continues aside to her .My dear child , I know that the captain had a great deal of confidence in you .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes , he had .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Well then , listen . Some one wishes to come here before the casket is removed some one who must not be seen .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Very well . She may . v. WoltersamazedWhat ——? She ——?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Why , it must be the lady .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: What lady ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: The lady for whom he let himself be shot .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: What ! You know ——?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: She had to come , of course . Who else should it be ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: H 'm ! Well then , listen carefully . If the undertaker — or any other stranger — should still be here when it begins to grow dark , throw on a wrap and wait at the door downstairs until a carriage stops . Will you ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Certainly I will . And Tempski ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Yes , Tempski , faithful as he is ——

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Tempski was never around in those days . v. Wolterslooking at her in astonishmentOh — so Tempski — was never — around — in those days ! H 'm ! Well then , I 'll undertake to get rid of Tempski myself . Thank you , my child .Gives her his hand , then aloud .I have another errand , but I 'll be back soon .Goes out at the right .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: What did the lieutenant want of you ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Nothing in particular — something about the wreaths . Kellermanncoming in from the backYes , with all those wreaths , we 'll have to have an extra carriage for the flowers . He was a fine man , he was — a highly respected man ! And on horseback ! Why , I 've won every time I bet on him ! Ah , yes , but sooner or later they all have to come to me !

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: And he was such a kind master ! He was just like a child sometimes — so light-hearted and happy — like a little boy ! Lately , to be sure , he —The bell rings .Well , Daisy !

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Who has stood without moving , lost in thought .I guess Tempski will go .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes , yes , you 're right . Tempski is outside . Tempskibrings in a wreath , sobbingF-from — our — major .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Why , Tempski , it 's perfectly natural that the major ——

sp.speaker: Tempski
sp.p: From — our — major .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Take the wreath from him , Daisy .

lg.stage: She does so . Tempski goes out , crying .
lg.l: From his major that must go on the coffin !

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I 'll do it . Kellermannin doubtDo n't you think ——?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes , let her ; she looks after everything .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: But nail it tightly , little lady — else it 'll fall off when they 're carrying him to the church .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes , yes .Goes out back with the wreath . During the following conversation , the strokes of a hammer are heard .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Everything is so well arranged here . I do n't see why they 've got to take him to the church .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: The official statement is that it will prevent any demonstration in the street . You know , the town folks have n't taken very kindly to this murdering business of late . But , of course , that 's not the real reason . The truth of the matter is that several very influential ladies would like to attend the funeral without being seen . H 'm !— love never dies , they say . Ah , the captain was no saint , I can tell you !

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: What do you know about it ?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Oh , well , there 's a lot of talk about the veiled figures that used to go in and out of here at twilight . And if these mirrors could speak —! That reminds me — I 'd almost forgotten — we must cover the mirrors .Daisy appears in front of the curtain . She is staring into space .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: But since the casket is to be taken away in less than an hour — what 's the use ?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: That does n't make any difference . The mirrors have got to be draped . It would be a blemish on my art — and I would n't answer for it .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Daisy !

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes , mother , dear .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Go get a pair of lace curtains to hang over the mirrors .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes , mother , dear .She does not stir .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Daisy ! You 're not listening .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes I am , mother , dear . You asked me to —Falters .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: I asked you to fetch a pair of lace curtains .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes , mother , dear .Goes out , left .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Now that the child is n't here — tell me , Herr Kellermann , do you know anything about the cause of the duel ? We 're all groping in the dark here at the house .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Well , they 're saying all sorts of things . But the dead are my friends . I never say anything against them . It 's a business principle with me .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes — but the man who shot him , is he still walking around free as air ?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Yes , that 's the way with these fine folks . They fall upon one another like highwaymen . Your honour or your life ! The man who survives can laugh . The man who falls — well , he falls into my arms . But , see here , getting into a duel with that fellow , that Baron Renoir — why it was nothing short of suicide ! I tell you , where that man goes , no grass grows ! On the turf , at the card-table , with the women — always the same story . That man shot him down like a rabbit . Oh , of course , it 's always a fine thing to lay down your life for a woman . That 's a phrase that ——

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Do you really think that a woman ——?

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Sh ! Here comes your little girl .Daisy enters with two vases , which she is carrying very carefully .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: What 's that you 're bringing ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I stopped and filled them first .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: But you were to get a pair of lace curtains !

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , forgive me , mother , dear . I thought you said vases . I 'll goExit with the vases .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: I do n't know what 's come over the child ! Why , she 's been such a help these days — thought of everything , wanted to do everything herself .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: A nice little girl — how old is she ?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Seventeen , her last birthday .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Is she at school ?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: She 's been going to the Art Institute . She wants to teach drawing .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: I suppose the captain thought a lot of her ?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Oh , dear me , yes . She was always around him from the time that she was a mere child . They used to play together out in the yard like two little kittens ! Of course , when she grew older , that sort of thing stopped . But lately , when he seemed so worried , I ——

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: So he seemed worried , did he ?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes , indeed . I 've had my suspicions for the last two months . Well , when he seemed so worried , I used to manage to send her in to him pretty often . She read aloud to him — and so on .Daisy enters with a couple of curtains , and a dark coat on her arm .

sp.speaker: Kellermann
sp.p: Thanks , thanks , little lady .Takes the curtains from her and stands on a chair under one of the mirrors .What lovely Venetian lace ! Ah , yes , every mirror comes to this sooner or later !

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I 'd like to get a breath of fresh air , would you mind , mother , dear ? I feel so ——

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Yes , yes , dear . Go out for a little while .Daisy puts on her coat .Kellermannin front of the other mirrorWhy , here 's a little bunch of flowers ! DaisyeagerlyOh , please , please , let me have it . Kellermannblowing off the dustIf it does n't fall to pieces .Hands it to her .Ah , yes , many , many loved him ! He had a beautiful life , he had a beautiful death , and , as for a beautiful funeral — just leave that to Kellermann !Takes his hat .I 'll be back again for the procession . Good evening , ladies .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Good evening .To Daisy , seeing her take off her coat .I thought you said you were going out ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , well , I 've changed my mind now .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: I 'm glad , because one feels so — so alone in here . Daisywith a glance backwardBut we are not alone yet . Frau Mulbridgeshuddering slightly

sp.speaker: That 's just it
sp.p: Daisystaring straight before her

sp.speaker: I 'm not afraid
sp.p: Frau Mulbridge . Tell me something , Daisy , dear . Were n't you in there last night ? Daisyalarmed

sp.speaker: Last night ? I ?
sp.p: Frau Mulbridge . Yes , at the coffin .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: What should I be doing at the coffin ?

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Well , I thought I heard some one go past the door .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: You must have been dreaming , mother , dear .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Very likely . I have n't been sleeping well these nights . See here , Daisy , perhaps he 's left us something — you , at least — tell me , have n't you been thinking about that sometimes ? Daisyapart , with a glance at the clockIf she does n't come soon ——!

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: What 's that you were saying ?The bell rings . Daisy starts .Why , what 's the matter with you ?v. Wolters enters .v. Wolterscalling

sp.speaker: Tempski !
sp.p: Tempskiat the threshold , in military attitudeHere , Lieutenant !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Hurry over to the garrison church and see if everything is ready .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Why , Kellermann will see ——

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: And then go — or no — stay there until the casket arrives . Do you understand ?

sp.speaker: Tempski
sp.p: At your command , Lieutenant .He goes out .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: That 's attended to . And now , my dear Frau Mulbridge , there 's something that I want to confide to you . A visitor is coming here presently — a lady .Frau Mulbridge glances anxiously at Daisy , who nods .She is not to be seen by any one — except Daisy . Daisy , it appears , used to open the door for her sometimes in former days .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Daisy —? What does this mean ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , Tempski might have gossiped , you know .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: And so he let you open the door ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I never gossip , mother .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: I 'm finding things out now ! Why did I never hear of this before ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , you were always in the stables with father in the evening .

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: And there I was trying to keep this child from any knowledge of the things that went on in here — and he ——

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: We 've no time for that now , Frau Mulbridge . Daisy , you will watch outside , wo n't you ? Frau MulbridgeprotestingOh , that 's too —— DaisyfirmlyYes , I 'll watch .The bell rings softly .Should I ——?v. Wolters nods .Frau Mulbridgecalling her backDaisy !Daisy goes out without noticing her mother .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: May I ask , Frau Mulbridge , that you ——

sp.speaker: Frau Mulbridge
sp.p: Very well . We have served him faithfully , and I 'll not start making any trouble now at the end .Exit , left . v. Wolters goes to the door at the right , listens , and then opens it cautiously . The Unknown Lady enters . She is heavily veiled , dressed entirely in black , and carries a spray of white roses . As she enters , she staggers slightly and leans against the writing-table for support .v. Wolterswho has softly locked the doorMay I show you the way , Countess ?The Lady shakes her head and motions questioningly toward the back . v. Wolters nods , and she goes out through the curtained doorway . After a short pause , v. Wolters opens the door at the right .v. WolterscallingDaisy !Daisy appears at the threshold .Kindly see that no one enters the house while this lady is here — no one , do you understand ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , yes , I understand very well .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: It may be that she has something else to say to me . If the men should come for the casket before she has left , take them around the other way . Keep the main entrance clear .

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: No , that would n't be safe .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Well , what shall we do ? Daisybreathing heavilyI 'll — think of something .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: His death grieves you , too , dear child ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Me ? Oh , yes — me too .She goes out . v. Wolters walks to and fro , pauses to listen in front of the curtain , turns on the electric lamp , again walks to and fro , etc . At a slight movement of the curtain , he stops , expectant . The Lady , still veiled , comes forward slowly until she has reached one of the chairs on the left . A pause .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Ah , Herr von Wolters — to let them close the coffin before I — I had seen him — I must confess , I had not expected that of you , Herr von Wolters .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I did n't dare prevent it , Countess — just because of your coming . It was the only way to have the house to ourselves .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Do n't call me countess , Herr von Wolters . I am not a countess here .Glancing toward the door .I am only an unhappy woman whom no one in this house knows , whom no one is to know .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Would n't you care to rest for a moment ?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Are we quite safe here ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Quite . The little girl who , you say , is not unknown to you , is outside at the entrance . I have told her mother of your visit and she will not enter the house . If you wish , however , we can lock the door .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Yes , do . Or , no , perhaps it would be better not to — in case any one ——

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Throws back her veil , revealing a very beautiful face , which is deathly pale and wears an expression of the deepest affliction . She sinks into the chair . A pause .I wanted to lay my roses on his breast . Ah , Herr von Wolters , I loved that man with an infinite love . Perhaps grief will give my life a new and holier meaning — who knows ? We seek beauty — and find grief . Tell me , Herr von Wolters , you were his best friend , did you never suspect ——?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Never , never .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: And when you received my letter early this morning asking you to come at once — not even then ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I could draw — various conclusions — from that .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: For instance ——?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Oh , please — really , you must excuse me ——

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: No , Herr von Wolters . We are here — but why do n't you sit down ?He does so .We are here together , you and I , to hold the last rites over our sainted dead . His friend and his beloved who else has any right to be here ? Herr von Wolters , I have given you my full confidence — I have made a strange confession to you . You will not betray me ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: And so , in this sacred hour , there must be no concealment between us . Answer me now . What does the world say ? v. WoltersembarrassedThe world says so many things , Countess .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Tell me , to what extent has my name been associated with this affair ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I can n't conceal the fact from you , Countess . Your name is mentioned . The LadythoughtfullyYes , that 's what my husband says .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: But please let me add that not a shadow , not the slightest suspicion , has ever ——

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: But what else can they think ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: My dear Countess , when a woman is as beauti — I mean , that when a woman is the centre of so much interest , it 's not surprising that some notice was taken of the attentions which he — The Ladysomewhat impatiently

sp.speaker: Yes — but ——?
sp.p: v. Wolters . It naturally was observed that my friend ——

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Our friend had a — what shall I say — a susceptible heart . We knew that , who knew him so well . This was not the first time he had — been interested in a woman . And that was why I arranged to have him seen in our house as little as possible — lately , not at all .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: That fact did not escape notice , Countess . And as Baron Renoir was frequently seen with you — instead of —— The Ladysomewhat excitedDo n't mention that name , Herr von Wolters ! I can n't stand it ! What could have possessed that man Renoir —? But do tell me the rest . I 've heard only the merest details . They 've only told me what they thought necessary .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: No one knows what actually occurred between the two men . He begged me to ask no questions . You know , he was so reserved of late . It may be that certain expressions which passed between them a few days ago — after they had been drinking — had something to do with it — no one knows . Perhaps there was some insult which was given in private — and which neither of them would make public . The assurance that the injury , whatever it may have been , was irreparable , must satisfy us .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Oh , how I hate that man Renoir !— quite apart from the trouble which he has gotten me into ! My husband warned me against him long ago . “ That scoundrel will compromise you some day , ” he said , “ and then I 'll have to fight a duel with him . ” Instead — this ! Oh , you poor , poor darling ! And now , when all was so quiet and peaceful between us !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: My dear Countess , if you think that the change which came over him in the last few months betokened peace and quiet —— The LadynervouslyI do n't know anything about that ! It was n't my fault ! Was I to blame if he insisted on having notions ? Tell me one thing , Herr von Wolters , did he die easily ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: No one dies easily , Countess .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Was he still living when they reached the house ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: No , he died on the field .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Do you know my first name , Herr von Wolters ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Certainly . The LadyhesitatingDid he — by any chance — speak — that name ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: That would have betrayed his secret , Countess .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: I only meant — at the very last — when he was no longer — conscious .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: No , Countess . But — pardon me , I do n't want to be indelicate — but did he ever call you by some little — little term of endearment — some —Stops , embarrassed .

sp.speaker: The Lady

My dear Herr von Wolters , our intimacy was of a different sort .

I were looking a blind man in the eyes !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Would you like to have me remove them ?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: No , no . Never mind . I want to ask you something , Herr von Wolters . Tell me , what do you think of me ? v. WoltersconfusedWhat do you mean , Countess ?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: I want to know what I have done that I should be doomed to bring so much sorrow into the lives of others . I had only just left school when a strange young man shot himself under my window . It was on my account that my husband was transferred here from his former garrison . Tell me , what mark of Cain do I bear that all men follow me ? I dress as simply as I can . I never go out without a double veil . Sometimes I have actually been tempted to throw vitriol in my face ! v. WolterscandidlyOh , that would have been a shame , Countess ! The LadyseverelyHerr von Wolters !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Yes , Countess , to mar that image of divinity would be a sin — and I do not hesitate to repeat it beside the coffin of my friend .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Do n't !Reaches him her hand , which he kisses respectfully .Dear me , how strange it seems ! Yesterday we scarcely knew one another — those few visits at my house do n't count . To-day — this short conversation — and here we are , sitting side by side , the guardians of a secret which will be buried forever with him . It will , Herr von Wolters ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Ah , my dear Countess , please do not offend me .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Very well , I shall not worry . Did you love him very dearly ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I thought a great deal of him , Countess . He took care of me when I was a young fellow quite alone in the world . He was so — Really , I do n't know how I shall —breaking down .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Courage , dear friend ! We must both try to be brave . v. WoltersfirmlyThank you , Countess . You will not have to reprove me again .

lg.l: You evaded my question before . Do you consider me very guilty , Herr von

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: He loved you , Countess . That makes you holy in my eyes .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: I thank you for that word — little as I deserve it . It has never been my way to undervalue myself . But your opinion meant so much to me —— v. WolterspuzzledWhat difference could my humble opinion ——

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Do n't say that , my dear friend . There are few people — perhaps not even my own husband — who have ever seen me as you see me at this moment — so weak , so helpless , so — I had almost said — unguarded . Remember that — and spare me .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I hope that I have not been inconsiderate , Countess .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Putting her hand to her brow , stammering .No , no , no ; it 's — it 's grieving for him that makes me lose my wits . The world had so long set me on a pedestal that I thought I belonged there . Now I feel as if I were torn down . Now I lie there — Herr von Wolters , pay no attention to me !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: If I could only help you , Countess ! The Ladysmiling sorrowfullyHelp me — you ? And yet , why not ? His friend and his beloved ! It is we , you and I , who are paying the last honours to the dead . Who could know his worth better than we ? Whose grief could be more eloquent than ours ? No , no , no — I must not talk . Ah , I see him before me now with his bright , careless smile — his conqueror 's smile ! I suppose you never were courted by women as he was ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: My dear Countess , I lead a fairly quiet , uneventful life .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: But you 're not — you 're not a Puritan , are you ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I must let others judge of that , Countess .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Oh ! I should like to cry out my sorrow to the whole world — say to them all , “ You sordid souls , you could n't know how much I loved him ! What do I care if you damn me , if you —— ”The bell rings . She starts .There 's the bell ! v. WoltersreassuringlyProbably just a wreath .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: And if it 's not — a ——?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: What is it , Herr von Wolters ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Who rang ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: It was a wreath . v. Woltersto The LadyJust as I supposed . The Ladyto DaisyCome here , dear .Daisy comes forward .You used to open the door for me , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: But you do n't know who I am ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: You 'll not try to find out ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , no .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Was he fond of you ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Oh , yes .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: And have you been crying since he died ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: You 're a pretty little girl . DaisygoingHas my lady any more questions ?

sp.speaker: The Lady

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: It did seem though , as if she were waiting for something .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: If you will pardon me for the suggestion , it was surely not — not for money .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: By the way , this incident reminds me of something I was just about to — Herr von Wolters , are you my friend ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: If you consider me worthy of that distinction , Countess .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Most assuredly . Well , Herr von Wolters , there is something that troubles me — something that desecrates my grief , if I may use the word . There 's the anxiety — the fear that — Yes , yes — I must tell you all . Herr von Wolters , he has my letters . Do you understand ?He nods .Did n't he give you something for me — a small , sealed package , perhaps — nothing ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: You are forgetting , Countess , that I was ignorant of all this until a short time ago .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Yes , that 's true . H 'm — it 's really too bad . Who has the keys ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Why , he gave them to me just before the duel . I have them with me .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: You 've looked through the writing-table ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Yes , I had to hand over his papers to the legal authorities . I did n't consider myself entitled to touch his private correspondence at present .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: He made a will the day before the duel .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Really ? In whose favor ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: What ! Did n't he make any allusion — nothing ——?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: The only thing he said was that he had named me as executor .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: But he had no relatives . Who is to inherit his large fortune ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: As I 've said , I do n't know . However , he made a remark that I did n't quite understand , and that I — pardon me — would rather not repeat , if you do n't mind .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Oh , please !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: It might give you pain , Countess . The LadysadlyNothing can give me pain after this .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Well , he said with a decided emphasis — though perhaps he did not intend that I should notice it — he said , “ The one who loved me best shall be my heir . ”

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: What ! He said that ? Who could have loved him best if not I ?Terrified .For God 's sake , Herr von Wolters !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Do n't be alarmed , Countess . That would be too grotesque .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Perhaps this is his revenge .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Revenge ? On you ? What for ?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: No , no — I 'm quite out of my senses , I — But , as you have the keys , you wo n't mind doing me this slight favour .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: What favour , Countess ?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Search for the letters with me — now . It seems to me your duty , not only as a friend but as a gentleman .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Pardon me , my dear Countess , you were certainly his last — perhaps his only great love . But his life was varied — and if we were to open his desk now — I really do n't know what we might find there .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: You mean there would be letters from other ——?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: I must say no more .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Well , I 'll shut my eyes . I 'll only look for my own handwriting .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: The will is to be opened in a few days , Countess . He has doubtless inserted a clause authorising me as executor to return certain papers to their owners — or destroy them .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Ah , I see you 're a Puritan , after all .— No , no , I 'll not trouble your conscience . This loyalty which you bear him to the very grave is so beautiful , so poetical , and I feel so near to you because of it —Putting her hand over her eyes .Oh , those curtains in front of the mirrors ! They make me feel as if I were dead myself ,v. Wolters is about to tear them down .No , no — do n't . Thanks . Tell me , how long will it be before the will is opened ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Unfortunately , the day is not yet appointed .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: I shall not sleep a moment until then . Not even my love , my grief , can outweigh this terrible fear . My honour , my future , my life — everything is at stake ! v. Woltersamazed

sp.speaker: Countess !
sp.p: The Lady . Please stop calling me Countess .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Forgive me . What should I ——?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Call me your friend . I want to be that . From this day you become closer to me than any other being in all the world . Are you not the legacy , as it were , that our dear dead has left me ?— Ah , you and I must become like brother and sister , two beings who have — nothing — to conceal from one another . Herr von Wolters , will you be my guide , my confidant — my friend ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Countess ! My dear , dear Countess ! The LadysoftlyBut you 're not to ——

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Forgive me . Your kindness to me makes me feel so — confused — I ——

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Why should it ? I feel certain that if he could see us at this moment , he himself would join our hands together .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Countess , if you ever need a man who would let himself be torn to pieces for you ——

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: No , not that . I only want you to take this great weight from my soul .

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Ah , Countess , I am a man of my word .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: And that 's what you call being torn to pieces for me ? v. WolterstremblingWhether I can answer for this to him and to my own conscience — whether I can ever again think of him — without shame — will depend upon what we shall find in there .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: But you will open it ?A pause .Herr von Wolters , you 'll not let me die of fear and distraction ?

sp.speaker: v. Wolters

The Ladyshuddering involuntarilyNo — no !v. Wolters turns the key in the keyhole unavailingly .Wo n't it work ?— Heavens , why your hand is trembling . Let me have it . v. sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Perhaps he burned everything . The Ladyspringing to her feetAnd perhaps not !— Who knows ?— This is the way he played with the honour of the woman who gave him all ! This is my thanks ! This is the action of a gentleman !

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: No gentleman , Countess , can do more than let himself be shot for a woman .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Who asked him to do it ? Was it my fault if jealousy of Renoir drove him mad ? And perhaps this is really his revenge ! Perhaps we 'll live to see even more interesting disclosures !— This is my reward ! This —Daisy appears at the door in the centre .What do you want ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I beg your pardon . My lady is looking for — letters ?

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: So you 've been in there eavesdropping , have you ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I brought in a wreath .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Well , what do you know about my letters ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Here they are .Takes a small package of letters from her dress and hands it to The Lady .I intended to give them to you secretly when you left .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: Snatches the letters from her hand and looks at them .How do you happen to have these letters ? DaisywonderinglyWhy , how should I happen to have them ? He gave them to me .

sp.speaker: The Lady

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Because he knew that I would do exactly what he told me to do . The Ladyto v. WoltersCan you understand this ? v. WoltersgentlyWhat did he tell you to do , Daisy ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: He said to me , “ These letters belong to the lady who used to come to see me sometimes . No one is to know about her — not even Herr von Wolters .— When I am dead , the lady will ——

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: Did he say that ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Yes . “ When I am dead , the lady will probably come here again . If she does , give her these letters . If she does n't , then burn them with the others . ”

sp.speaker: v. Wolters
sp.p: What others ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: Those over there in the stove . The Ladyexamining the lettersLook at this ! Unsealed ! Unwrapped ! DaisysmilingHe knew that I would n't read them .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: I suppose from now on I shall be at your mercy !

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I do n't know you , my lady . And even if I did , you need have no fear . The Ladyto v. WoltersIs n't she kind ! Daisyalways respectfullyBut I should like to ask you a favour , my lady .

sp.speaker: The Lady
sp.p: What right have you to make such a shameless request of me ?

sp.speaker: Daisy
sp.p: I heard — forgive me , I did n't want to — I heard the way you spoke about him before . And it seems to me that your flowers no longer belong upon his coffin .

sp.speaker: The Lady

sp.p: The Lady .Stares at her through her lorgnette and smiles .Oh , really ! Daisyher bearing pure and proudThe night before he died I became — his wife .A long pause .
