sp.speaker: Liddy
sp.p: It seems to me that you 've turned the screw too far , mother .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: Well , what shall we do about it ? StruebelrisingPermit me to come to your aid , ladies . I 've had some experience with these old screws .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: Very kind indeed .Struebel busies himself with the instrument .

sp.speaker: Liddy
sp.p: Listen , mother . If the carriage has almost reached the top the princess can n't be far off . Would n't it be best , then , to watch for them on the road ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: Certainly , if you think that would be best , dear Liddy .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: This is not only an old screw , but it 's a regular perverted old screw !

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: Ah , really ?—Aside to her daughters .And if she should actually speak to us at this accidental meeting — and if we could present ourselves as the subjects of her noble fiance , and tell her that we live at her future home — just imagine what an advantage that would give us over the other women of the court !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: There , ladies ! We have now rescued the useful instrument to which the far-sightedness of mankind is indebted .

sp.speaker: Frau V. Halldorf
sp.p: Thanks , so much .— Pardon me , sir , but have you heard anything about the report that the princess is going to make the journey up here to-day ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: The princess ? The Princess of the Springs ? The Princess of the lonely villa ? The Princess who is expected at the iron spring every morning , but who has never been seen by a living soul ? Why , I am enormously interested . You would n't believe how much interested I am ! Liddywho has looked out , backThere — there — there — it is !

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: The carriage ?

sp.speaker: Liddy
sp.p: It 's reached the top already . It is stopping over there at the edge of the woods .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: She will surely enter it there , then . Come quickly , my dear children , so that it will look quite accidental .— Here is your money .She throws a coin to Rosa and unwraps a small package done up in tissue paper which she has brought with her .Here is a bouquet for you and here 's one for you . You are to present these to the princess .

sp.speaker: Milly
sp.p: So that it will look quite accidental — oh , yes !All three go out .

lg.l: Good heavens ! Could I —? I do n't believe it ! Surely she sits — Well ,
lg.stage: Goes up to the telescope and stops .
lg.l: I 'll go along with them , anyhow .
Have they all gone — all of them ?

sp.speaker: Rosa
sp.p: All of them . Frau Lindemannlooking toward the rightThere — there — two ladies and a lackey are coming up the footpath . Mercy me ! How my heart is beating !— If I had only had the sofa re-covered last spring !— What am I going to say to them ?— Rosa , do n't you know a poem by heart which you could speak to the princess ?Rosa shrugs her shoulders .They 're coming through the court now !— Stop putting your arms under your apron that way , you stupid thing !— oh dear , oh dear ——

body.stage: The door opens . A Lackey in plain black livery enters , and remains standing at the door . He precedes The Princess and Frau Von Brook . The Princess is a pale , sickly , unassuming young girl , wearing a very simple walking costume and a medium-sized leghorn hat trimmed with roses . Frau Von Brook is a handsome , stately , stern-looking woman , in the thirties . She is well dressed , but in accordance with the simple tastes of the North German nobility .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Who is the proprietor of this place ?

sp.speaker: Frau Lindemann
sp.p: At your command , your Highness .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: reprovinglyI am the maid of honour .— Where is the room that has been ordered ? Frau Lindemannopens the door , leftHere — at the head of the stairs — my lady .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Would your Highness care to remain here for a few moments ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Very much , dear Frau von Brook .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Edward , order what is needed for Her Highness and see that a room next to Her Highness is prepared for me . I may assume that these are your Highness 's wishes ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Why certainly , dear Frau von Brook .The Lackey , who is carrying shawls and pillows , goes out with Rosa , left .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Mais puisque je te dis , Eugenie , que je n'ai pas sommeil . M'envoyer coucher comme une enfant , c'est abominable .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Mais je t'implore , cherie , sois sage ! Tu sais , que c'est le medecin , qui ——

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Ah , ton medecin ! Toujours cette corvee . Et si je te dis ——

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Chut ! My dear woman , would n't it be best for you to superintend the preparations ?

sp.speaker: Frau Lindemann
sp.p: I am entirely at your service .About to go out , left .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: One thing more . This veranda , leading from the house to the grounds — would it be possible to close it to the public ?

sp.speaker: Frau Lindemann
sp.p: Oh , certainly . The guests as often as not sit out under the trees .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Very well , then do so , please .Frau Lindemann locks the door .We may be assured that no one will enter this place ?

sp.speaker: Frau Lindemann
sp.p: If it is desired , none of us belonging to the house will come in here either .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: We should like that .

sp.speaker: Frau Lindemann
sp.p: Very well .Exit .

lg.l: Really , you must be more careful , darling . If that woman had understood

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: What would have been so dreadful about it ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Oh , my dear child ! This mood of yours , which is due to nothing but your illness — that reminds me , you have n't taken your peptonised milk yet — this is a secret which we must keep from everyone , above all from your fiance . If the Grand-Duke should discover —— The Princessshrugging her shouldersWell , what of it ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: A bride 's duty is to be a happy bride . Otherwise ——

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Otherwise ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: She will be a lonely and an unloved woman . The Princesswith a little smile of resignation

sp.speaker: Ah !
sp.p: Frau v. Brook . What is it , dear ?The Princess shakes her head .And then think of the strain of those formal presentations awaiting you in the autumn ! You must grow strong . Remember that you must be equal to the most exacting demands of life .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Of life ? Whose life ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Ah , what good does it do to talk about it ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Yes , you are right . In my soul , too , there are unhappy and unholy thoughts that I would rather not utter . From my own experience I know that it is best to keep strictly within the narrow path of Duty .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And to go to sleep .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Ah , it is n't only that .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Look out there ! See the woods !— Ah , to lie down on the moss , to cover oneself with leaves , to watch the clouds pass by high above ——

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: softeningWe can do that , too , sometime . The Princesslaughing aloud

p.stage: The Lackey appears at the door

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Try to , for my sake .Aloud .Does your Highness command —— The Princesssmiling and sighingYes , I command .They go out , left .The stage remains empty for several moments . Then Struebel is heard trying the latch of the back door .Struebel 's Voice . Hullo ! What 's up ! Why is this locked all of a sudden ? Rosa !— Open up ! I 've got to look through the telescope ! Rosa ! Wo n't you ?— Oh , well , I know how to help myself .He is seen walking outside of the glass-covered veranda . Then he puts his head through the open window at the right .Not a soul inside ?—Climbs over .Well , here we are . What on earth has happened to these people ?Unlocks the back door and looks out .Everything deserted . Well , it 's all the same to me .Locks the door again .But let 's find out right away what the carriage has to do with the case .Prepares to look through the telescope . The Princess enters cautiously through the door at the left , her hat in her hand . Without noticing Struebel , who is standing motionless before the telescope , she goes hurriedly to the door at the back and unlocks it .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Startled at the sound of the key , turns around .Why , how do you do ?The Princess , not venturing to move , glances back at the door through which she has entered .Would n't you like to look through the telescope a while ? Please do .The Princess , undecided as to whether or not she should answer him , takes a few steps back toward the door at the left .Why are you going away ? I wo n't do anything to you . The PrincessreassuredOh , I 'm not going away .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: That 's right . But — where have you come from ? The door was locked . Surely you did n't climb through the window as I did ? The PrincessfrightenedWhat ?— You came — through the window ?——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Of course I did . The Princessfrightened anewThen I had ratherAbout to go back .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Oh , my dear young lady , you just stay right here . Why , before I 'd drive you away I 'd pitch myself headlong over a precipice ! The Princesssmiling , reassuredI only wanted to go out into the woods for half an hour .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Oh , then you 're a regular guest here at the Inn ? The PrincessquicklyYes — yes , of course .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: And of course you drink the waters down below ? The Princessin a friendly wayOh , yes , I drink the waters . And I 'm taking the baths , too .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Two hundred metres up and down every time ! Is n't that very hard on you ? Heavens ! And you look so pale ! See here , my dear young lady , do n't you do it . It would be better for you to go down there — that is — Oh , forgive me ! I 've been talking without thinking . Of course , you have your own reasons — It 's decidedly cheaper up here . I know how to value a thing of that sort . I 've never had any money in all my life ! The Princesstrying to seem practicalBut when one comes to a watering-place , one must have money . Struebelslapping himself on the chestDo I look to you as if I drank iron ? Thank Heaven , I can n't afford such luxuries ! No ; I 'm only a poor fellow who earns his miserable pittance during vacation by acting as a private tutor — that 's to say , “ miserable ” is only a figure of speech , for in the morning I lie abed until nine , at noon I eat five , and at night seven , courses ; and as for work , I really have n't a thing to do ! My pupil is so anaemic — why , compared to him , you 're fit for a circus rider ! The Princesslaughing unrestrainedlyOh , well , I 'm rather glad I 'm not one .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Dear me , it 's a business like any other .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Like any other ? Really , I did n't think that .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: And pray , what did you think then ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , I thought that they were — an entirely different sort of people .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: My dear young lady , all people are “ an entirely different sort . ” Of course we two are n't . We get along real well together , do n't we ? As poor as church mice , both of us ! The Princesssmiling reflectivelyWho knows ? Perhaps that 's true . StruebelkindlyDo you know what ? If you want to stay down there — I 'll tell you how one can live cheaply . I have a friend , a student like myself . He 's here to mend up as you are . I feed him up at the house where I 'm staying .Frightened at a peculiar look of The Princess 's .Oh , but you must n't be — No , I should n't have said it . It was n't decent of me . Only , let me tell you , I 'm so glad to be able to help the poor fellow out of my unexpected earnings , that I 'd like to be shouting it from the housetops all the time ! Of course , you understand that , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: You like to help people , then ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Surely — do n't you ? The Princessreflecting

sp.speaker: No . There 's always so much talk about it , and the whole thing
sp.p: immediately appears in the newspapers .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: What ? If you help some one , that appears ——? The Princessquickly correcting herselfI only mean if one takes part in entertainments for charity ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Oh , yes , naturally . In those things they always get some woman of rank to act as patroness , if they can , and she sees to it , you may be sure , that the newspapers make a fuss over it . The PrincessdemurelyOh , not every ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Just try to teach me something I do n't know about these titled women ! Besides , my dear young lady , where is your home — in one of the large cities , or ——?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , no . In quite a small town — really more like the country .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Then , I 'm going to show you something that you probably never saw before in all your life .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh do ! What is it ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: A princess ! H 'm — not a make-believe , but a real , true-blue princess !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , really ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Yes . Our Princess of the Springs .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And who may that be ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Why , Princess Marie Louise .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Of Geldern ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Do you know her ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Why , certainly .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Really ? I thought that she lived in great retirement .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Well , that does n't do her any good . Not a bit of it . And because you are such a jolly , good fellow , I 'm going to tell you my secret . I 'm in love with this princess !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: You can n't imagine what a comfort it is . The fact is , every young poet has got to have a princess to love .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Are you a poet ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Ca n't you tell that by looking at me ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: I never saw a poet before .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Never saw a poet — never saw a princess ! Why , you 're learning a heap of things to-day ! The PrincessassentingH 'm — And have you written poems to her ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Why , that goes without saying ! Quantities of ‘ em !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , please recite some little thing — wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: No , not yet . Everything at the proper time .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Ah , yes , first I should like to see the princess .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: No , first I am going to tell you the whole story .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , yes , yes . Please do .Sits down .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Well , then — I had hardly heard that she was here before I was dead in love with her . It was just as quick as a shot , I tell you . Just as if I had waited all my life long to fall in love with her . Besides , I also heard about her beauty — and her sorrow . You see , she had an early love affair . The PrincessdisconcertedWhat ? Are they saying that ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Yes . It was a young officer who went to Africa because of her — and died there .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And they know that , too ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: What do n't they know ?— But that 's a mere detail — it does n't concern me . Even the fact that in six months she will become the bride of a grand-duke — even that can make no difference to me . For the present she is my princess .— But you 're not listening to me !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , yes I am !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Do you know what that means — my princess ? I 'll not give up my princess — not for anything in all the world !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: But — if you do n't even know her ——?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: I do n't know her ? Why , I know her as well as I know myself !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Have you ever met her , then ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: I do n't know of any one who has ever met her . And there 's not a soul that can tell what she looks like . It is said that there were pictures of her in the shop-windows when she first came , but they were removed immediately . In the morning a great many people are always lurking around the Springs trying to catch a glimpse of her . I myself have gotten up at six o'clock a couple of times — on the same errand — and if you knew me better , you 'd realise what that meant . But not a sign of her ! Either she has the stuff brought to her house , or she has the power of making herself invisible .The Princess turns aside to conceal a smile .After that , I used to hang around her garden — every day , for hours at a time . Until one day the policeman , whom the managers of the Springs have stationed at the gates , came up to me and asked me what on earth I was doing there . Well , that was the end of those methods of approach ! Suddenly , however , a happy thought struck me . Now I can see her , and have her near to me as often as I wish .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Why , that 's very interesting . How ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Yes , that 's just the point . H 'm , should I risk it ? Should I take you into my confidence ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: You promised me some time ago that you would show her to me .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Wait a second .Looks through the telescope .There she is . Please look for yourself .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: But I am —She , too , looks through the telescope .Actually , there is the garden as plain as if one were in it .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: And at the corner window on the left — with the embroidery-frame — that 's she .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Are you absolutely certain that that is the princess ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Why , who else could it be ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , ‘ round about a princess like that — there are such a lot of people . For instance , there is her waiting-woman , there 's the seamstress and her assistants , there 's ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: But my dear young lady , if you only understood anything about these matters , you would have been certain at the very first glance that it was she — and no one else . Observe the nobility in every motion — the queenly grace with which she bends over the embroidery-frame ——

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: How do you know that it 's an embroidery-frame ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Why , what should a princess be bending over if not an embroidery-frame ? Do you expect her to be darning stockings ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: It would n't hurt her at all !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Now , that 's just one of those petty , bourgeois notions which we ought to suppress . It 's not enough that we have to stick in this misery , but we 'd like to drag her down , too — that being far above all earthly care ——

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , dear me !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: What are you sighing about so terribly ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Tell me , would n't you like to have a closer acquaintance with your princess , sometime ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Closer ? Why should I ?— Is n't she close enough to me , my far-away princess ?— for that 's what I call her when I talk to myself about her . And to have her still closer ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Why , so that you could talk to her and know what she really was like . StruebelterrifiedTalk to her ! Heaven forbid ! Goodness gracious , no ! Just see here — how am I to face a princess ? I 'm an ordinary fellow , the son of poor folks . I have n't polished manners — I have n't even a decent tailor . A lady like that — why , she 'd measure me from top to toe in one glance .— I 've had my lessons in the fine houses where I 've applied as tutor . A glance from boots to cravat — and you 're dismissed !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And you think that I —correcting herself— that this girl is as superficial as that ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: “ This girl ” ! Dear me , how that sounds ! But , how should I ever succeed in showing her my real self ? And even if I should , what would she care ?— Oh , yes , if she were like you — so nice and simple — and with such a kindhearted , roguish little twinkle in her eye ——!

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Roguish — I ? Why so ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Because you are laughing at me in your sleeve . And really I deserve nothing better .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: But your princess deserves something better than your opinion of her .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: How do you know that ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: You really ought to try to become acquainted with her sometime .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: No , no , no — and again no ! As long as she remains my far-away princess , she is everything that I want her to be — modest , gracious , loving . She smiles upon me dreamily . Yes , she even listens when I recite my poems to her — and that can n't be said of many people ! And as soon as I have finished , she sighs , takes a rose from her breast , and casts it down to the poet .— I wrote a few verses yesterday about that rose , that flower which represents the pinnacle of my desires , as it were . The PrincesseagerlyOh , yes . Oh , please , please !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Well , then , here goes . H 'm — “ Twenty roses nestling close —— ”

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: What ? Are there twenty now ? StruebelseverelyMy princess would not have interrupted me .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh please — forgive me .

lg.l: Twenty years would I gladly give
Could I but ask a rose of thee
And ask it not in vain .
Twenty roses thou dost not need
— Why , pearls and rubies are thine !—
With nineteen thou'dst be just as fair ,
And one would then be mine !
And twenty years of rose-wreathed joy
Would spring to life for me —
Yet twenty years could ne'er suffice

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: How nice that is ! I 've never had any verses written to me b ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Ah , my dear young lady , ordinary folks like us have to do their own verse-making !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And all for one rose !— Dear me , how soon it fades ! And then what is left you ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: No , my dear friend , a rose like that never fades — even as my love for the gracious giver can never die .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: But you have n't even got it yet !

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: That makes no difference in the end . I 'm entirely independent of such externals . When some day I shall be explaining Ovid to the beginners , or perhaps even reading Horace with the more advanced classes — no , it 's better for the present not to think of reaching any such dizzy heights of greatness — well , then I shall always be saying to myself with a smile of satisfaction , “ You , too , were one of those confounded artist fellows — why , you once went so far as to love a princess ! ”

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And that will make you happy ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Enormously !— For what makes us happy after all ? A bit of happiness ? Great heavens , no ! Happiness wears out like an old glove .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Well , then , what does ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Ah , how should I know ! Any kind of a dream — a fancy — a wish unfulfilled — a sorrow that we coddle — some nothing which suddenly becomes everything to us . I shall always say to my pupils — “ Young men , if you want to be happy as long as you live , create gods for yourselves in your own image ; these gods will take care of your happiness . ”

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And what would the god be like that you would create ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Would be ? Is , my dear young lady , is !— A man of the world , a gentleman , well bred , smiling , enjoying life — who looks out upon mankind from under bushy eyebrows , who knows Nietzsche and Stendhal by heart , and —pointing to his shoeswho is n't down at the heels — a god , in short , worthy of my princess . I know perfectly well that all my life long I shall never do anything but crawl around on the ground like an industrious ant , but I know , too , that the god of my fancy will always take me by the collar when the proper moment comes and pull me up again into the clouds . Yes , up there I 'm safe .— And your god , or rather your goddess — what would she look like ? The PrincessthoughtfullyThat 's not easy to say . My goddess would be — a quiet , peaceful woman who would treasure a secret , little joy like the apple of her eye , who would know nothing of the world except what she wanted to know , and who would have the strength to make her own choice when it pleased her .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: But that does n't seem to me a particularly lofty aspiration , my dear young lady .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Lofty as the heavens , my friend .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: My princess would be of a different opinion .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Do you think so ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: For that 's merely the ideal of every little country girl .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Not her ideal — her daily life which she counts as naught . It is my ideal because I can never attain it .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Oh . I say , my dear young girl ! It can n't be as bad as that ! A young girl like you — so charming and — I do n't want to be forward , but if I could only help you a bit !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Have you got to be helping all the time ? Before , it was only a cheap lunch , now it 's actually ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Yes , yes , I 'm an awful donkey , I know , but —— The PrincesssmilingDo n't say any more about it , dear friend ! I like you that way . Struebelfeeling oppressed by her superiorityReally you are an awfully strange person ! There 's something about you that — that —

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: I can n't exactly define it .— Tell me , were n't you wanting to go into the woods before ? It 's so — so oppressive in here .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oppressive ? I do n't find it so at all — quite the contrary .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: No , no — I 'm restless . I do n't know what — at all events , may I not escort you —? One can chat more freely , one can express himself more openly — if one —Takes a deep breath .The PrincesssmilingAnd you are leaving your far-away princess with such a light heart ? StruebelcarelesslyOh , she ! She wo n't run away . She 'll be sitting there tomorrow again — and the day after , too !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: And so that is your great , undying love ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Yes , but when a girl like you comes across one 's path ——

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: Hurrying in and then drawing back in feigned astonishment .Oh ! Liddy and Millysimilarly

sp.speaker: Oh !
sp.p: Struebel . Well , ladies , did n't I tell you that you would n't find her ? Princesses do n't grow along the roadside like weeds !

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: Disregarding him ceremoniously .The infinite happiness with which this glorious event fills our hearts must excuse in some measure the extraordinary breach of good manners which we are committing in daring to address your Highness . But , as the fortunate subjects of your Highness 's most noble fiance , we could not refrain from ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Well , well ! What 's all this ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: — from offering to our eagerly awaited sovereign a slight token of our future loyalty . Liddy ! Milly !Liddy and Milly come forward , and , with low court bows , offer their bouquets .My daughters respectfully present these few flowers to the illustrious princess ——

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: I beg your pardon , but who is doing the joking here , you or ——?

body.stage: Frau v. Brook enters . The Princess , taken unawares , has retreated more and more helplessly toward the door at the left , undecided whether to take flight or remain . She greets the arrival of Frau v. Brook with a happy sigh of relief .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: severelyPardon me , ladies . Apparently you have not taken the proper steps toward being presented to Her Highness . In matters of this sort one must first apply to me . I may be addressed every morning from eleven to twelve , and I shall be happy to consider your desires .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Halldorf
sp.p: with dignityI and my children , madame , were aware of the fact that we were acting contrary to the usual procedure ; but the impulse of loyal hearts is guided by no rule . I shall be glad to avail myself of your very kind invitation .

body.stage: All three go out with low curtsies to The Princess .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: What forwardness !— But how could you come down without me ?— And what is that young man over there doing ? Does he belong to those people ?

body.stage: The Princess shakes her head . Struebel , without a word , goes to get his hat which has been lying on a chair , bows abruptly , and is about to leave .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Oh , no ! That would n't be nice . Not that way ——

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: amazedWhat ?— What !— Why , your Highness ——!

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Let me be , Eugenie . This young man and I have become far too good friends to part in such an unfriendly , yes , almost hostile , fashion .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Your Highness , I am very much —— The Princessto StruebelYou and I will certainly remember this hour with great pleasure , and I thank you for it with all my heart . If I only had a rose with me so as to give you your dear wish !— Eugenie , have n't we any roses with us ?

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Your Highness , I am very much ——

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Examining herself and searching among the vases .Well , how are we going to manage it ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: I most humbly thank — your Highness — for the kind intention .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: No , no — wait !Her glance falls upon the hat which she is holding in her hand with a sudden thought .I have it !— But do n't think that I 'm joking .— And we 'll have to do without scissors !She tears one of the roses from the hat .I do n't know whether there are just twentyHolding out one of the roses to him .Well ?— This rose has the merit of being just as real as the sentiment of which we were speaking before — and just as unfading .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Is this — to be — my punishment ?The Princess smilingly shakes her head .Or does your Highness mean by it that only the Unreal never fades ?

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: That 's exactly what I mean — because the Unreal must always dwell in the imagination .

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: So that 's it ! Just as it is only the far-away princesses who are always near to us .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Permit me to remark , your Highness that it is high time ——

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: As you see , those who are near must hurry away .Offering him the rose again .Well ?

sp.speaker: Struebel
sp.p: Is about to take it , but lets his hand fall .With the far-away princess there —pointing downit would have been in harmony , but with the —Shakes his head , then softly and with emotion .No , thanks — I 'd rather not .He bows and goes out .

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Smiling pensively , throws away the artificial flower .I 'm going to ask my fiance to let me send him a rose .

sp.speaker: Frau v. Brook
sp.p: Your Highness , I am very much — surprised !

sp.speaker: The Princess
sp.p: Well , I told you that I was n't sleepy .
